publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for Humphrey Robinson ... and for Humphrey Moseley ...,

note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

div.head: Scaena Prima.
div.stage: Enter Incubo the Bayliff, Diego the Hoſt.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: SIgnior Don Diego, and mine Hoſt, ſave thee.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: I thank you Mr Bayly.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: O the block.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Why, how ſhould I have anſwered?

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Not with that
Negligent rudeneſs: But I kiſs your hands
Signior Don Incubo de Hambre, and then
My titles; Maſter Bayly of Caſtil-blanco:
Thou nere wilt have the elegancy of an Hoſt;
I ſorrow for thee, as my friend and goſſip:
No ſmoak, nor ſteam out-breathing from the kitchen?
There's litle life i'th harth then.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: I, there, there,
That is his friendſhip, hearkning for the ſpit,
And ſorrow that he cannot ſmel the pot boil.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Strange
An Inne ſhould be ſo curſt, and not the ſign
Blaſted, nor withered; very ſtrange, three days now,
And not an egg eat in it, or an onyon.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: I think they ha' ſtrew'd the high-wayes with cal-traps, I,
No horſe dares paſs 'em; I did never know
A week of ſo ſad doings, ſince I firſt
Stood to my ſign-poſt.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Goſſip, I have found
The root of all; kneel, pray, it is thy ſelf
Art cauſe thereof: each perſon is the founder
Of his own fortune, good, or bad; but mend it,
Call for thy cloak, and rapier.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Do, call,
And put 'em on in haſte: Alter thy fortune,
By appearing worthy of her: Doſt thou think
Her good face ere wil know a man in cuerpo?
In ſingle body, thus? in hoſe, and doblet?
The horſe boyes garb? baſe blank, and half blank cuerpo?
Did I, or Mr Dean of Civil our neighbor
Ere reach our dignities in cuerpo, thinkſt thou,
In ſquirting hoſe, and doublet? Signior, no,
There went more to't: there were cloaks, gowns, caſſocks
And other paramentos; Call, I ſay,
His cloak, and rapier here. Enter Hoſteſſe.

sp.speaker: Hoſteſ.
sp.l: What means your worſhip?

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Bring forth thy husbands Sword: ſo hang it on,
And now his cloak, here, caſt it up; I mean
Goſſip, to change your luck, and bring you gueſts.

sp.speaker: Hosteſ.
sp.l: Why? is there charm in this?

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Expect; now walk,
But not the pace of one that runs on errands;
For want of gravity in an Hoſt, is odious:
You may remember Goſſip, if you pleaſe,
(Your wife being then th' Infanta of the Gipſies,
And your ſelf governing a great mans Mules then)
Me a poor Squire at Madrid attending
A Maſter of Ceremonies; But a man, beleeve it,
That knew his place to the gold weight, and ſuch
Have I heard him oft ſay, ought every Hoſt
Within the Catholique kings dominions
Be in his own houſe.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: A Maſter of Ceremonies:
At leaſt vice-maſter, and to do nought in cuerpo,
That was his maxime; I wil tell thee of him:
He would not ſpeak with an Ambaſſadors Cook,
See a cold bake-meat from a forreign part
In cuerpo: had a dog but ſtaid without,
Or beaſt of quality, as an Engliſh cow,
But to preſent it ſelf, he would put on
His Savoy chain about his neck, the ruff
And cuffs of Holland, then the Naples hat
With the Rome hat-band, and the Florentine agat,
The Millain Sword, the Cloak of Genua, ſet
With Flemiſh buttons, all his given peeces
To entertain 'em in, and complement Knock within.
With a tame Coney, as with the Prince that ſent it.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Liſt, who is there?

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: A gueſt and 't be thy wil.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Look Spowſe, cry luck, and we be encounter'd: ha?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Luck then, and good, for 'tis a fine brave gueſt,
With a brave horſe.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Why now, beleeve of cuerpo Enter Theodoſia.
As you ſhal ſee occaſion: go, and meet him.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Look to my horſe, I pray you, wel.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: He ſhal Sir.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Oh how beneath his rank and call was that now?
Your horſe ſhal be entreated as becomes
A horſe of faſhion, and his inches.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: O.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Look to the Cavalier: what ailes he? ſtay
If it concern his horſe, let it not trouble him,
He ſhal have all reſpect the place can yeeld him
Either of barley, or freſh ſtraw.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Good Sir
Look up.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: He ſincks, ſomewhat to caſt upon him,
Hee'l go away in cuerpo elſe.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: What, wife!
O your hot waters quickly, and ſome cold
To caſt in his ſweet face.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Alas, fair flowre?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Do's any body entertain his horſe?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Yes, Lazaro has him.

div.stage: Enter Hoſteſſe with a glaſſe of water.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Go you ſee him in perſon.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Sir, taſte a litle of this, of mine own water,
I did diſtil't my ſelf; ſweet Lilly look upon me,
You are but newly blown, my pretty Tulip.
Faint not upon your ſtalk, 'tis firme and freſh
Stand up, ſo, bolt upright, you are yet in growing.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Pray you let me have a chamber.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: That you ſhall Sir.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: And where I may be private, I intreat you.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: For that introth Sir, we ha' no choice: our houſe
Is but a vent of need, that now and then
Receives a gueſt, between the greater towns
As they come late; onely one room,

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: She means Sir, it is none
Of thoſe wild, ſcatter'd heaps, call'd Innes, where ſcarce
The Hoſt is heard, though he wind his horn t'his people,
Here is a competent pile, wherein the man,
Wife, Servants, all doe live within the whiſtle

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Onely one room.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: A pretty modeſt quadrangle
She will deſcribe to you.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Wherein ſtands two Beds Sir
We have, and where, if any gueſt do come,
He muſt of force be lodg'd, that is the truth Sir.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: But if I pay you for both your beds, methinks
That ſhould alike content you.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: That it ſhall Sir.
If I be paid, I am praid.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Why, ther's a Ducket
Will that make your content?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: O the ſweet face on you:
A Ducket? yes, and there were three beds Sir,
And twice ſo many rooms, which is one more,
You ſhould be private in 'em all, in all Sir,
No one ſhould have a peece of a bed with you
Not Maſter Deane of Civill himſelf, I ſwear
Though he came naked hither, as once he did
When h'had like t'have been tane a bed with the Moore
And guelt by her Maſter: you ſhall be as private,
As if you lay in's owne great houſe, that's haunted,
Where no body comes, they ſay:

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: I thank you Hoſteſſe.
Pray you will you ſhew me in.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Yes marry will I Sir,
And pray that not a flea, or a chink vex you

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: You forget ſupper: Goſſip: move for ſupper

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: 'Tis ſtrange what love to a beaſt may do, his Horſe
Threw him into this fit.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: You ſhall excuſe me
It was his being in Cuerpo, meerly caus'd it.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Do you think ſo Sir?

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Moſt unlucky Cuerpo,
Naught els, he looks as he would eat partridge,
This gueſt; ha' you em ready in the houſe?
And a fine peece of kid now? and freſh garlick,
With a Sardina, and Zant oile? how now?
Has he beſpoke? what will he have a brace,
Or but one partridge, or a ſhort leg'd hen,
Daintyly carbonado'd?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: 'Laſſe the dead
May be as ready for a Supper as he.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: He has no mind to eat, more then his ſhadow:

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Say you.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.l: How do's your worſhip

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: I put on
My left ſhoo firſt to day, now I perceive it,
And skipt a bead in ſaying 'em ore; els
I could not be thus croſs'd: He cannot be
Above ſeventeen; one of his years, and have
No better a ſtomach?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: And in ſuch good clothes too

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.l: Nay, thoſe do often make the ſtomach worſe, wife,
That is no reaſon.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: I could at his years Goſſips
(As temperate as you ſee me now) have eaten
My brace of ducks, with my half gooſe, my cony,
And drink my whole twelve Marvedis in wine
As eaſie as I now get down three olyffs.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.l: And with your temperance-favour, yet I think
Your worſhip would put to't at ſix and thirty
For a good wager; and the meal in too.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: I do not know what mine old mouth can do,
I ha not prov'd it lately

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.l: That's the grief Sir.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: But is he without hope then gone to bed?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: I fear ſo Sir, has lock'd the door cloſe to him
Sure he is very ill.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: That is with faſting,
You ſhould ha told him Goſſip, what you had had,
Given him the inventury of your kitchen,
It is the picklock in an Inne, and often
Opens a cloſe barr'd ſtomach: what may he be trob?
Has he ſo good a Horſe?

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.l: Oh a brave Jennet,
As ere your worſhip ſaw.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: And he eats

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.l: Strongly,

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: A mighty ſolaſciſme, heaven give me patience,
What creatures has he?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: None.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: And ſo well cloath'd,
And ſo well mounted?

sp.speaker: Di g.
sp.l: That's all my wonder Sir,
Who he ſhould be; he is attir'd and hors'd
For the Conſtables ſon of Spaine.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: My wonders more
He ſhould want appetite: well a good night
To both my Goſſips: I will for this time
Put off the thought of ſupping; In the morning
Remember him of breakfaſt pray you,

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: 'T ſhall Sir,

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.l: A hungry time Sir.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: We that live like myce
On others meat, muſt watch when we can get it Exit Incubo.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Yes, but I would not tell him: Our fair gueſt
Says, though he eat no ſupper, he will pay for one.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.l: Good news: we'l eat it ſpouſe, 't his health,
'Twas politickly done t'admit no ſharers.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Look to the Mules there, wher's mine Hoſt?

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.l: Here Sir.
Another Fayerie.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Bleſſe me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: From what ſweet Hoſteſſe?
Are you affraid o' your gueſts?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: From Angels Sir,
I think ther's none but ſuch come here to night,
My houſe had never ſo good luck afore
For brave fine gueſts; and yet the ill luck on't is
I cannot bid you welcome.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: No?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Not lodge you Sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Not, Hoſteſſe?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: No in troth Sir, I do tell you
Becauſe you may provide in time: my beds
Are both tane up by a yong Cavalier
That wil, and muſt be private.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: He has paid Sir
For all our Chambers.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Which is one: and Beds
Which I already ha' told you are two: But Sir,
So ſweet a creature, I am very ſorry
I cannot lodge you by him; you look ſo like him
Yo'are both the lovelieſt peeces.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What train has he?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: None but himſelf.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: And wil no leſs then both deds
Serve him?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: H'as given me a ducket for 'em.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: O.
You give me reaſon Hoſteſſe: Is he handſome,
And yong do you ſay?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: O Sir, the delicat'ſt fleſh
And fineſt clothes withall, and ſuch a horſe,
With ſuch a Sadle.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Shee's in love with all.
The horſe, and him, and Sadle, and clothes: good woman,
Thou juſtifieſt thy Sex; lov'ſt all that's brave:
Sure though I lye o'th ground, ile ſtay here now
And have a ſight of him: you'l give me houſe-room,
Fire, and freſh meat for money: gentle Hoſteſſe
And make me a pallat?

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Sir ſhee ſhal do reaſon:
I underſtood you had another gueſt: Goſſips
Pray you let his Mule be lookt too: have good ſtraw,
And ſtore of bran: And Goſſip do you hear,
Let him not ſtay for ſupper: what good fowle ha' you?
This gentleman would eat a pheaſant.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: 'Laſs Sir;
We ha' no ſuch.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: I kiſs your hands fair Sir.
What ha' you then? ſpeak what you have? I 'me one Sir
Here for the Catholique King, an Officer
T' enquire what gueſts come to theſe places; you Sir
Appear a perſon of quality, and 'tis fit
You be accommodated: why ſpeak you not,
What ha' you woman? are you afraid to vent
That which you have?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: This is a moſt ſtrange man;
'T appoint my meat.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: The half of a cold hen Sir,
And a boil'd quarter of kid, is all i'th houſe.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Why all's but cold; let him ſee it fourth,
Cover, and give the eye ſome ſatisfaction,
A Travellers ſtomach muſt ſee bread and ſalt,
His belly is nearer to him, then his kindred:
Cold hen 's a pretty meat Sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What you pleaſe;
I am reſolv'd t' obey.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: So is your kid,
With pepper, garlick, and the juice of an Orenge,
She ſhal with ſallads help it, and cleane lynnen;
Diſpatch: what news at Court Sir?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Faith new tires
Moſt of the Ladies have: the men old Suits,
Only the Kings fool has a new coat
To ſerve you.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: I did gheſs you came from thence Sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: But I do know I did not.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: I miſtook Sir.
What hear you of the Archdukes?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Troth your queſtion.

div.stage: Enter Hoſteſſe and Servants with Table.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Of the French buſineſs, What?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: As much.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: No more?
They ſay the French: O that's wel: come I'le help you:
Have you no jibblets now? or a broild raſher
Or ſome ſuch preſent diſh t'aſſiſt?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Not any Sir.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: The more your fault; you nev'r ſhould be without
Such aydes: what cottage would ha' lackt a pheaſant
At ſuch a time as this? wel, bring your hen,
And kid forth quickly.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: That ſhould be my prayer
To ſcape his inquiſition.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Sir, the French,
They ſay are divided 'bout their match with us,
What think you of it.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: As of naught to me Sir.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Nay it's as litle to me too: but I love
To ask after theſe things, to know the affections
Of States, and Princes, now and then for bettring.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Of your own ignorance.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Yes Sir:

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Many do ſo.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: I cannot live without it: what do you hear
Of our Indian Fleet; they ſay they are well return'd.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I had no venture with 'em Sir; had you?

div.stage: Enter Hoſteſſe and Servants with meat.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Why do you ask Sir?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'Cauſe it might concern you,
It do's not me.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: O here's your meat come.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Thanks,
I welcome it at any price.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Some ſtools here,
And bid mine Hoſt bring Wine, ile try your kid,
If he be ſweet: he looks wel: yes, he is good;
Ile carve you ſir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: You uſe me too too princely:
Taſt, and carve too.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: I love to do theſe offices.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I think you do: for whoſe ſake?

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: For themſelves ſir,
The very doing of them is reward.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'Had little faith would not beleeve you Sir.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.p: Goſſip ſome wine. Enter Diego with wine.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Here 'tis: and right St Martyn.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Meaſure me out a glaſs.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I love the humanity
Us'd in this place:

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Sir, I ſalute you here.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I kiſs your hands Sir.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Good wine; it wil beget an appetite:
Fil him; and ſit down, Goſſip, entertain
Your noble gueſt here, as becomes your title.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Pleaſe you to like this wine Sir?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: J diſlike
Nothing mine Hoſt, but that I may not ſee
Your conceal'd gueſt: here's to you.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: In good faith Sir,
I wiſh you as wel as him: would you might ſee him.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: And wherefore may he not:

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: 'Has lock'd himſelf Sir
Up, and has hir'd both the beds o' my wife
At extraordinary rate.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Ile give as much
If that will do't, for one, as he for both;
What ſay you mine Hoſt, the door once open
Ile fling my ſelf upon the next bed to him
And there's an end of me till morning; noiſe
I will make none.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: I wiſh your worſhip well —but

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: His honour is engag'd: And my ſhe Goſſip
Hath paſt her promiſe, hath ſhe not?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Yes truely:

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: That toucheth to the credit of the houſe:
Well, I will eate a little, and think: how ſay you ſir
Unto this brawn o'th hen?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I ha' more minde
To get this bed ſir.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Say you ſo: Why then
Giv't me agen, and drink to me: mine Hoſt
Fill him his wine: thou'rt dull, and do'ſt not praiſe it,
I eate but to teach you the way Sir.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Sir:
Find but the way to lodge me in this chamber
Ile give mine Hoſt two duckets for his bed,
And you ſir two realls: here's to you

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Excuſe me,
I am not mercenary: Goſſip pledge him for me,
Ile think a little more; but ev'n one bit
And then talke on: you cannot interrupt me.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: This peece of wine ſir coſt me

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Stay: I have found:
This little morcell: and then: here's excellent garlick:
Have you not a bunch of grapes now: or ſome Bacon
To give the mouth a relliſh?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Wife, do you hear?

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: It is no matter. Sir, give mine Hoſt your duckets.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: How Sir?

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Do you receive 'em: I will ſave
The honeſty of your houſe: and yours too Goſſip,
And I will lodge the Gentleman: ſhew the Chamber.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Good Sir do you hear.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Shew me the Chamber.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Pray you Sir,
Do not diſturb my gueſts.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Diſturb? I hope
The Catholique King ſir, may command a lodging
Without diſturbing in his vaſſails houſe,
For any Miniſter of his, emploid
In buſineſs of the State. Where is the door?
Open the door, who are you there? within?
In the Kings name. Theodoſia within.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: What would you have?

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Your key ſir,
And your door open: I have here command
To lodge a Gentleman, from the Juſtice, ſent
Upon the Kings affairs.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: Kings and neceſſities
Muſt be obey'd:' the key is under the door.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: How now ſir, are you fitted? you ſecur'd?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Your two reals are grown a peece of eight.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Excuſe me Sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'Twill buy a hen; and wine
Sir, for to morrow. Exit. Phil.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: I do kiſſe your hands Sir
Well this will bear my charge yet to the Gallies
Where I am owing a ducket: whither this night
By the Moons leave Ile march: for in the morning
Early they put from Port S. Maries. Ex. al but Diego.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Lazaro Enter Lazaro.
How do the horſes?

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: Would you would go and ſee Sir,
A — of all Jades, what a clap h'as given me:
As ſure as you live maſter he knew perfectly
I couzend him on's Oats: he lookt upon me
And then he ſneerd, as who ſhould ſay take heed ſirrah:
And when he ſaw our half peck, which you know
Was but an old Court diſh: lord how he ſtampt:
I thought 't had been for joy, when ſuddenly
He cuts me a back caper with his heels
And takes me juſt o'th' crupper: down came I
And all my ounce of Oates: Then he neigh'd out
As though he had had a Mare by'th taile.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Faith Lazaro
We are to blame to uſe the poor dumb ſerviters
So cruelly.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: Yonder's this other gentlemans horſe
Keeping our Lady eve: the devill a bit
Has got ſince he came in yet: there he ſtands
And looks, and looks, but 'tis your pleaſure ſir
He ſhall look lean enough: has hay before him
But 'tis as big as hemp, and will as ſoon choak him,
Unleſs he eate it butter'd: he had four ſhoos
And good ones when he came: 'tis a ſtrange wonder
With ſtanding ſtill he ſhould caſt three.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: O Lazaro
The devils in this trade: truth never knew it
And to the devill we ſhall travell Lazaro
Unleſs we mend our manners: once every week
I meet with ſuch a knock to molefie me
Sometimes a dozen to awake my conſcience
Yet ſtill I ſleep ſecurely.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: Certain Maſter
We muſt uſe better dealing.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: 'Faith for mine own part
Not to give ill example to our iſſues,
I could be well content to ſteal but two girths,
And now and then a ſaddle cloth: change a bridle
Onely for exerciſe.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: If we could ſtay there
There were ſome hope on's Maſter: but the devill is
We are drunk ſo early we miſtake whole Saddles
Sometimes a horſe; and then it ſeems to us too
Every poore Jade has his whole peck, and tumbles
Up to his ears in clean ſtraw, and every bottle
Shews at the leaſt a dozen; when the truth is Sir
Ther's no ſuch matter, not a ſmell of provinder,
Not ſo much ſtraw, as would tye up a horſe tail,
Nor any thing ith' rack, but two old cobwebs
And ſo much rotten hay as had been a hens neſt.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Well, theſe miſtakings muſt be mended Lazaro,
Theſe apparitions, that abuſe our ſences,
And make us ever apt to ſweep the manger
But put in nothing; theſe fancies muſt be forgot
And we muſt pray it may be reveal'd to us
Whoſe horſe we ought in conſcience to couzen,
And how, and when: A Parſons horſe may ſuffer
A little greazing in his teeth, 'tis wholſome;
And keeps him in a ſober ſhuffle: and his Saddle
May want a ſtirrop, and it may be ſworn
His learning lay on one ſide, and ſo brok it:
Has ever Oates in's cloak-bag to prevent us
And therefore 'tis a meritorious office
To tythe him ſoundly.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: And a Grazier may
For thoſe are pinching puckfoyſts and ſuſpitious:
Suffer a myſt before his eyes ſometimes too,
And think hee ſees his horſe eat half a buſhel:
When the truth is, rubbing his gums with ſalt,
Till all the skin come off: he ſhal but mumble
Like an old woman, that were chewing brawn,
And drop 'em out again.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: That may do wel too,
And no doubt 'tis but venial: But good Lazaro
Have you a care of underſtanding horſes,
Horſes with angry heels, gentlemens horſes,
Horſes that know the world: let them have meat
Till their teeth ake; and rubbing till their ribbs
Shine like a wenches forehead; they are devils

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: And look into our dealings: as ſure as we live
Theſe Courtiers horſes are a kind of Welſh prophets,
Nothing can be hid from 'em: For mine own part
The next I cozen of that kind, ſhal be founderd,
And of all four too: Ile no more ſuch complements
Upon my crupper.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Steal but a litle longer
Till I am lam'd too, and wee'l repent together,
It wil not be above two daies.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: By that time
I ſhal be wel again, and all forgot Sir.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.l: Why then ile ſtay for thee. Exit.

div.head: Scaena ſecunda.
div.stage: Enter Theodoſia and Phillipo on ſeveral Beds.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Oh,—ho-? oh—ho?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Oh—oh? heart—heart—heart—heart?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: When wilt thou break?— break, break, break?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Ha?
I would the voice were ſtrong, or I neerer,

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Shame, ſhame, eternal ſhame? what have I done?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Done?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: And to no end: what a wild Jorney
Have I more wildly undertaken?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Jorney?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: How without counſel? care? reaſon? or fear?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Whither wil this fit carry?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: O my folly:

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: This is no common ſickneſs.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: How have I left
All I ſhould love, or keep? ô heaven.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How do you gentle Sir?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Alas my fortune

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: It ſeems your ſorrow oppreſſes: pleaſe your goodneſs
Let me bear half Sir: a divided burthen
Is ſo made lighter.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Oh,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: That ſigh betrayes
The fulneſs of your grief:

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: I, if that grief
Had not bereft me of my underſtanding,
I ſhould have wel remembred where I was,
And in what company; and clapt a lock
Upon this tongue for talking.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Worthy Sir
Let it not add to your grief, that I have heard
A ſigh, or groan come from you: That is all Sir:

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Good Sir no more: you have heard too much I fear,
Would I had taken poppy when I ſpake it.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: It ſeems you have an ill belief of me
And would have feard much more, had you ſpoke ought
I could interpret. But beleeve it Sir
Had I had means to look into your breaſt,
And tane you ſleeping here, that ſo ſecurely
I might have read, all that your woe would hide
I would not have betrayd you.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Sir that ſpeech
Is very noble, and almoſt would tempt
My need to truſt you.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: At your own election,
I dare not make my faith ſo much ſuſpected
As to proteſt again: nor am I curious
To know more then is fit.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Sir I wil truſt you
But you ſhal promiſe Sir to keep your bed,
And whatſoe'er you hear, not to importune
More I beſeech you from me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Sir I wil not.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Then I am proan to utter.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: My faith for it.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: If I were wiſe, I yet ſhould hold my peace
You wil be noble.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: You ſhal make me ſo
If you'l but think me ſuch.

sp.speaker: Theo
sp.l: I do: then know
You are deceiv'd with whom you have talk ſo long.
I am a moſt unfortunate loſt woman.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Do not ſtir Sir: I have here a Sword.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Not I ſweet Lady: of what blood, or name.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: You'l keep your faith.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Ile periſh elſe.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Beleeve then
Of birth too noble for me, ſo deſcended—
I am aſhamd, no leſs then I am affrighted.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Fear not: by all good things, I will not wrong you.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: I am the daughter of a noble Gentleman
Born in this part of Spain: my fathers name Sir:
But why ſhould I abuſe that reverence
When a childs duty has forſaken me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: All may be mended: in fit time too: ſpeak it

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Alphonſo, ſir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Alphonſo? what's your own name?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Any baſe thing you can invent.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Deal truely.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: They call me Theodoſia

sp.speaker: Phi●.
sp.l: Ha? and love
Is that that hath chang'd you thus?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Ye have obſerv'd me
Too neerly Sir, 'tis that indeed: 'tis love Sir.
And love of him (oh heavens) why ſhould men deal thus?
Why ſhould they uſe their arts to cozen us?
That have no cunning, but our fears about us?
And ever that too late to; no diſſembling
Or double way but doating: too much loving?
Why ſhould they find new oaths, to make more wretches?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What may his name be?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Sir a name that promiſes
Me thinks no ſuch ill uſage: Mark-antonio
A noble neighbours Son: Now I muſt deſire ye
To ſtay a while: elſe my weak eyes muſt anſwer.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I will: —Are ye yet ready? what is his quality?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: His beſt a theef Sir: that he would be known by;
Is, heir to Leonardo, a rich Gentleman:
Next, of a handſome body, had heaven made him
A minde fit to it. To this man, my fortune,
(My more then purblind fortune) grave my faith▪
Drawn to it by as many ſhews of ſervice
And ſigns of truth, as ever falſe tongue utter'd:
Heaven pardon all.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'Tis wel ſaid: forward Lady.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Contracted Sir, and by exchange of rings
Our ſouls deliver'd: nothing left unfiniſh'd
But the laſt work, enjoying me, and Ceremony.
For that I muſt confeſs was the firſt wiſe doubt
I ever made: yet after all this love ſir,
All this profeſſion of his faith; when dayly
And hourly I expected the bleſt prieſt
Hee left me like a dream, as all this ſtory
Had never been, nor thought of, why I know not;
Yet I have called my conſcience to confeſſion,
And every ſillable that might offend
I have had in ſhrift: yet neither loves law Signiour,
Nor ty of maidens duty, but deſiring
Have I tranſgreſt in: left his father too,
Nor whither he is gone, or why departed
Can any tongue reſolve mee: All my hope
(Which keeps mee yet alive, and would perſwade mee
I may be once more happy, and thus ſhapes mee
A ſhame to all my modeſt ſex) is this Sir,
I have a Brother and his old Companion,
Studient in Sallimanca, there my laſt hope
If hee bee yet alive, and can be loving
Is left mee to recover him: For which travel
In this Sute left at home of that dear Brothers
Thus as you find mee, without fear, or wiſdom,
I have wander'd from my father, fled my friends,
And now am only child of hope and danger:
You are now ſilent Sir: this tedious ſtory
(That ever keeps mee waking) makes you heavy:
'Tis fit it ſhould do ſo: for that, and I
Can be but troubles.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: No, I ſleep not Lady:
I would I could: oh heaven is this my comfort.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: What aile you gentle Sir?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Oh.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Why do you groan ſo?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I muſt, I muſt; oh miſery.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: But now Sir
You were my comfort: if any thing afflict yee
Am not I fit to bear a part on't? and by your own rule.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: No; if you could heal, as you have wounded me,
But 'tis not in your power.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: I fear intemperance.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nay do not ſeek to ſhun mee: I muſt ſee you:
By heaven I muſt: hoa, there mine Hoſt: a Candle:
Strive not, I wil not ſtir ye.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Noble Sir
This is a breach of promiſe.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Tender Lady
It ſhal be none but neceſſary: hoa, there,
Some light, ſome light for heavens ſake.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Wil ye betray mee?
Are ye a gentleman?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Good woman:

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Sir. Enter Diego with a light.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: If I be prejudicial to you, curſe mee.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.l: Ye are early ſtirring ſir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Give mee your Candle
And ſo good morrow for a while.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.l: Good morrow Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: My Brother Don Philippo: nay Sir, kil mee
I ask no mercy Sir, for none dare know me,
I can deſerve none: As ye look upon me
Behold in infinite theſe foul diſhonors
My noble father, then your ſelf: laſt all
That bear the name of kindred, ſuffer in mee:
I have forgot whoſe child I am, whoſe Siſter:
Do you forget the pity tyed to that:
Let not compaſſion ſway you: you wil be then
As foul as I, and bear the ſame brond with me,
A favourer of my fault: ye have a ſword ſir,
And ſuch a cauſe to kil me in.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Riſe Siſter:
I wear no ſword for women: nor no anger
While your fair chaſtity is yet untouch'd.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: By thoſe bright ſtarrs, it is Sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: For my Siſter
I do beleeve ye: and ſo neer blood has made us
With the dear love I ever bore your vertues
That I wil be a Brother to your griefs too:
Be comforted, 'tis no diſhonor Siſter
To love, nor to love him you do: he is a gentleman
Of as ſweet hopes, as years, as many promiſes,
As there be growing truths, and great ones.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: O ſir!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Do not deſpair.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Can ye forgive?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Yes Siſter,
Though this be no ſmal error, a far greater.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: And think me ſtil your Siſter?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: My dear Siſter.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: And wil you counſel mee?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: To your own peace too:
Ye ſhal love ſtil.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: How good ye are?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: My buſineſs,
And duty to my father, which now drew mee
From Salimanca, I wil lay aſide
And only be your Agent to perſwade ye
To leave both love, and him, and wel retyre ye.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Oh gentle Brother.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I perceive 'tis folly:
Delayes in love, inore dangerous.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Noble Brother.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Fear not, ile run your own way: and to help you,
Love having rackt your paſſions beyond counſel:
Ile hazard mine own fame: whither ſhal we venture?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Alas, I know not Sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Come, 'tis bright morning
Let's walk out, and conſider: you'l keep this habit.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: I would ſir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Then it ſhal be: what muſt I cal ye?
Come, do not bluſh: pray ſpeak, I may ſpoil all elſe.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Pray cal me Theodoro. Enter Diego.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.l: Are ye ready?
The day draws on a pace: once more good morrow.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Good morrow gentle Hoſt: now I muſt thank ye:

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Who do'ſt thou think this is?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Were you a wench Sir
I think you would know before me.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Mine own Brother.

sp.speaker: Diego.
sp.l: By'th Maſſe your noſes are a kin: ſhould I then
Have been ſo barbarous to have parted Brothers?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: You knew it then.

sp.speaker: Diego.
sp.l: I knew 'twas neceſſary
You ſhould be both together: Inſtinct Signior
Is a great matter in an Hoſt.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: I am ſatisfied. Enter Pedro.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Is not mine Hoſt up yet?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Ile ſee.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Siſter, withdraw your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: Signiour Philippo

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Noble Don Pedro, where have you been this way?

sp.speaker: Pedr
sp.l: I came from Port S^t Maries, whence the Gallyes
Put this laſt tide, and bound for Barcellona,
I brought Mark-antonie upon his way.

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.l: Marc-antonie?

sp.speaker: Pedr
sp.l: Who is turn'd Soldier
And entertain'd in the new Regiment,
For Naples.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Is it poſſible?

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: And put they in at Barcellona?

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: So
One of the Maſters told me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Which way go you Sir?

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: Home:

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: And I for Civill: pray you Sir, ſay not
That you ſaw me, if you ſhall meet the queſtion,
I have ſome little buſineſſe

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: Were it leſſe Sir.
It ſhall not become me, to looſe the caution:
Shall we break-faſt together?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Ile come to you Sir:
Siſter you hear this: I beleeve your fortune
Begins to be propitious to you: we will hire
Mules of mine hoſt here: if we can himſelf
To be our guid, and ſtreight to Barcellona,
This was as happy news, as unexpected
Stay you, till I rid him away.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: I will. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: KNock at the door.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: 'Tis open Sir.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: That's all one
Knock when I bid you.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Will not your worſhip enter.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Will not you learn more manners Sir, and do that
Your Maſter bids ye; knock ye knave, or ile knock
Such a round peal about your pate; I enter
Under his roofe, or come to ſay god ſave ye
To him, the Son of whoſe baſe dealings has undone me.
Knock lowder, lowder yet: ile ſtarve, and rot firſt,
This open ayr is every mans.

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.l: within. Come in Sir.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: No, no Sir, I am none of theſe come in Sirs
None of thoſe viſitants: bid your wiſe Maſter
Come out, I have to talk unto him: go Sir

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.l: Your worſhip may be welcome.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Sir, I will not,
I come not to be welcome: good my three duckets
My pickell'd ſprat a day, and no oyl to't,
And once a year a cotten coat, leave prating
And tell your Maſter, I am here.

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.l: I will Sir.
This is a ſtrange old man. Exit.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I welcome to him!
Ile be firſt welcome to a Peſthouſe: Sirhah
Lets have your valour now caſde up, and quiet
When an occaſion calls, 'tis wiſdom in ye,
A Serving mans diſcretion: if you do draw
sp.stage: Enter Leonardo, and Don Zanchio (carried by two Servants in a chair.)
sp.l: Draw but according to your entertainment;
Five nobles worth of fury.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Signiour Alphonſo.
I hope no diſcontent from my will given,
Has made ye ſhun my houſe: I ever lov'd ye.
An credit me amongſt my fears 'tis greateſt
To miniſter offences.

sp.speaker: Alph
sp.l: O good Signiour
I know ye for Italian breed, fair tongu'd,
Spare your Appologies, I care not for'em,
As little for your love Sir; I can live
Without your knowledge; eat mine own, and ſleep
Without dependances, or hopes upon ye.
I come to aske my daughter.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Gentle Sir.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I am not gentle Sir, nor gentle will be
Till I have juſtice, my poor child reſtor'd
Your caper-cutting boy has run away with
Yong Signior-ſmooth-face, he that takes up wenches
With ſmiles, and ſweet behaviours, ſongs, and ſonnets,
Your high fed Jennet, that no hedge can hold
They ſay you bred him for a Stallion.

sp.speaker: Zanch.
sp.l: Fie Signiour, there be times, and terms of honour
To argue theſe things in, deſcidements able
To ſpeak ye noble gentlemen, ways punctuall
And to the life of credit, ye are too rugged.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I am too tame Sir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Will ye hear but reaſon?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: No, I will hear no reaſon: I come not hither
To be popt off with reaſon; reaſon then.

sp.speaker: Zanch.
sp.l: Why Signior, in all things there muſt be method
Ye choak the child of honour els, diſcretion,
Do you conceive an injury?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: What then Sir?

sp.speaker: Zanch.
sp.l: Then follow it in fair terms, let your ſword bite
When time calls, not your tongue.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I know Sir
Both when and what to do without directions,
And where, and how, I come not to be tutur'd,
My cauſe is no mans but mine own: you Signior
Will ye reſtore my daughter?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Who detains her?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: No more of theſe ſleight ſhifts

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Ye urge me Signior
With ſtrange unjuſtice: becauſe my Son has err'd

sp.speaker: Zanch
sp.l: Mark him.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Out of the heat of youth: do'ſt follow
I muſt be father of his crimes.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I ſay ſtill
Leave off your rhetorick, and reſtore my daughter.
And ſodainly: bring in your rebell too,
Mountdragon, he that mounts without commiſſion
That I may ſee him puniſhed, and ſeverely,
Or by that holy heaven, ile fire your houſe,
And ther's my way of honour.

sp.speaker: Zanch.
sp.l: Pray give me leave
Was not man made the nobleſt creature

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Well Sir.

sp.speaker: Zanch.
sp.l: Should not his mind then anſwer to his making,
And to his mind his actions, if this ought to be,
Why do we run a blind way from our worths,
And cancell our diſcretions, doing thoſe things
To cure offences, are the moſt offences?
We have rules of juſtice in us; to thoſe rules
Let us apply our angers: you can conſider
The want in others of theſe terminations,
And how unfurniſh'd they appear.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Hang others,
And where the wrongs are open, hang reſpects,
I come not to conſider.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Noble Sir,
Let us argue cooly, and conſider like men.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Like men!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Ye are too ſodain ſtill.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Like men Sir?

sp.speaker: Zanch
sp.l: It is fair language, and ally'd to honour.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Why, what ſtrange beaſt would your grave re|verence
Make me appear? like men!

sp.speaker: Zanch.
sp.l: Taſte but that point Sir,
And ye recover all.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I tell thy wiſdome
I am as much a man, and as good a man.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: All this is granted Sir.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: As wiſe a man.

sp.speaker: Zanch.
sp.l: Ye are not tainted that way.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: And a man
Dares make thee no man; or at beſt, a baſe man.

sp.speaker: Zanch.
sp.l: Fy, Fy, here wants much carriage.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Hang much carriage.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Give me good language ſirrah Signiour.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Give me my daughter.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I am as gentle as your ſelf, as free born.

sp.speaker: Zanch.
sp.l: Obſerve his way.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: As much reſpect ow'd to me.

sp.speaker: Zanch.
sp.l: This hangs together nobly.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: And for Civill
A great deal more it ſeems: go look your daughter.

sp.speaker: Zanch.
sp.l: There ye went well off Signiour.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: That rough tongue
You underſtand at firſt: you never think Sir
Out of your mightineſſe, of my loſſe: here I ſtand
A patient anvill, to your burning angers
Made ſubject to your dangers; yet my loſſe equall:
Who ſhall bring home my ſon?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: A whipping Beadle.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Why, is your daughter whoriſh?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Ha, thou dar'ſt not,
By heaven I know thou dar'ſt not.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I dare more Sir
If you dare be uncivill.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Laugh too, Pidgeon.

sp.speaker: Zanch.
sp.l: A fitter time for fames ſake: two weak Nurſes
Would laugh at this; are there no more days coming,
No ground but this to argue on? no ſwords left
Nor friends to carry this, but your own furies?
Alas! it ſhows too weakly.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Let it ſhow,
I come not here for ſhews: laugh at me ſirrah?
Ile give ye cauſe to laugh.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Ye are as like Sir
As any man in Spaine.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: By heaven I will,
I will brave Leonardo.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Brave Alphonſo,
I will expect it then.

sp.speaker: Zanch.
sp.l: Hold ye there both,
Theſe terms are noble.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Ye ſhall hear ſhortly from me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Now diſcreetly.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Aſſure your ſelf ye ſhall: do ye ſee this ſword Sir?
He has not caſt his teeth yet.

sp.speaker: Zanch.
sp.l: Rarely carried.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: He bites deep: moſt times mortall: Signiour
Ile hound him at the fair and home.

sp.speaker: Zanch.
sp.l: Still nobly.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: And at all thoſe that dare maintain ye.

sp.speaker: Zanch.
sp.l: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: How you ſhall pleaſe Sir, ſo it be fair, though cer|tain,
I had rather give you reaſon.

sp.speaker: Zanch.
sp.l: Fairly urg'd too.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: This is no age for reaſon, prick your reaſon
Upon your ſwords point.

sp.speaker: Zanch.
sp.l: Admirably follow'd.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: And there ile hear it: ſo till I pleaſe, live Sir. Exit

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: And ſo farewell, you'r welcome.

sp.speaker: Zanch.
sp.l: The end crowns all things
Signiour, ſome little buſineſſe paſt, this cauſe ile argue
And be a peace between ye, ift ſo pleaſe ye,
And by the ſquare of honour to the utmoſt:
I feel the old man's maſter'd by much paſſion,
And too high rackt, which makes him overſhoot all.
His valour ſhould direct at, and hurt thoſe
That ſtand but by as blenchers: this he muſt know too,
As neceſſary to his judgement, doting women
Are neither ſafe nor wiſe adventures: conceive me,
If once their wills have wander'd; nor is't then
A time to uſe our rages: for why ſhould I
Bite at the ſtone, when he that throws it wrongs me?
Do not we know that women are moſt wooers
Though cloſeſt in their carriage? Do not all men know,
Scarce all the compaſſe of the globe can hold 'em
If their affections be afoot? ſhall I then covet
The follys of a ſhe-fool, that by nature
Muſt ſeek her like, by reaſon be a woman,
Sink a tal ſhip becauſe the ſales defie me?
No, I diſdain that folly; he that ventures
Whilſt they are fit to put him on, has found out
The everlaſting motion in his ſcabbard.
I doubt not to make peace: and ſo for this time
My beſt love, and remembrance.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Your poor Servant. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena ſecunda.
div.stage: Enter Diego Hoſt, Philippo, and Theodoſia.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Where will our Horſes meet us?

sp.speaker: Hoſt Dieg.
sp.l: Fear not you Sir,
Some half mile hence, my worſhips man will ſtay us,
How is it with my young bloods? come, be joviall,
Let's travell like a merry flock of wild geeſe,
Every tongue talking.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: We are very merry;
But do you know this way Sir?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Is't not dangerous?
Methinks theſe woody thickets ſhould harbour knaves.

sp.speaker: Hoſt Die.
sp.l: I fear none but fair wenches: thoſe are theeves
May quickly rob me of my good conditions
If they cry ſtand once: but the beſt is Signiours
They cannot bind my hands; for any elſe,
They meet an equall knave, and there's my paſport:
I have ſeen fine ſport in this place, had theſe trees tongues,
They would tell ye pretty matters: do not you fear though
They are not every days delights.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What ſport Sir?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Why to ſay true, the ſport of all ſports.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What was't?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Such turning up of taffataes; and you know
To what rare whiſtling tunes they go, far beyond
A ſoft wind in the ſhrowds: ſuch ſtand there,
And down ith thother place; ſuch ſupplications
And ſubdiviſions for thoſe toys their honours,
One, as ye are a gentleman in this buſh,
And oh ſweet Sir, what mean ye? ther's a bracelet,
And uſe me I beſeech ye like a woman,
And her petition's heard: another ſcratches,
And crys ſhe will die firſt, and then ſwones: but certain
She is brought to life again, and does well after.
Another ſave mine honour, oh mine honour,
My husband ſerves the Duke, Sir, in his kitchen;
l have a cold pie for ye; fy, fy, fy gentlemen,
Will nothing ſatisfie ye, where's my husband?
Another crys, do ye ſee Sir how they uſe me,
Is there no law for theſe things?

sp.speaker: The●.
sp.l: And good mine Hoſt,
Do you call theſe fine ſports?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: What ſhould I call 'em,
They have been ſo call'd theſe thouſand years & upwards.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: But what becomes o'th' men?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: They are ſtript and bound,
Like ſo many Adams, with fig leafs afore 'em,
And there's their innocence.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Would we had known this?
Before we reacht this place.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Come, there's no danger,
Theſe are but ſometimes chances.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Now we muſt through.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Stand to it Signiors.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: No it needs not,
I know the face; 'tis honeſt.

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: What mine Hoſt:
Mine everlaſting honeſt Hoſt.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Maſſe Bayly:
Now in the name of an ill reckoning
What make you walking this round?

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: A — of this round,
And of all buſineſſe too, through woods, and raſcalls,
They have rounded me away a dozen duckets,
Beſides a fair round cloke: Some of 'em knew me,
Els they had caſed me like a cony too,
As they have done the reſt, and I think roſted me,
For they began to baste me ſoundly: my young Signiors,
You may thank heaven, and heartily, and hourly,
You ſet not out ſo early; ye had been ſmoak'd els
By this true hand ye had Sirs, finely ſmoakt,
Had ye been women, ſmockt too.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Heaven defend us.

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: Nay, that had been no prayer, there were thoſe
That run that prayer out of breath, yet fail'd too:
There was a Fryer, now ye talk of prayer,
With a huge bunch of beads, like a rope of onyons;
I am ſure as big, that out of fear and prayer,
In half an houre wore 'em as ſmall as bugles,
Yet he was flea'd too.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: At what houre was this?

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: Some two houres ſince.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Do you think the paſſage ſure now.

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: Yes, a rope take 'em, as it will, and bleſſe 'em,
They have done for this day ſure.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Are many riffled?

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: At the leaſt a dozen,
And there left bound.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: How came you free?

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: A curteſie
They uſe out of their rogueſhips, to bequeath
To one, that when they give a ſigne from far
Which is from out of danger; he may preſently
Releaſe the reſt, as I met you, I was going,
Having the ſigne from yonder hill to do it.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Alas poor men.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Mine Hoſt, pray go untie'em.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Let me alone for cancelling: where are they?

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: In every buſh like black birds, you cannot miſſe 'em

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: I need not ſtalk unto 'em. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: No, they'l ſtand ye,
My buſy life for yours Sir: you would wonder
To ſee the ſeverall tricks, and ſtrange behaviors
Of the poor raſcals in their miſeries,
One weeps, another laughs at him for weeping,
A third is monſtrous angry he can laugh
And crys, go too, this is no time; he laughs ſtill,
A fourth exhorts to patience: him a fift man
Curſes for tameneſſe; him a Fryer ſchools,
All hoot the Fryer: here one ſings a Ballad,
And there a little Curat confutes him,
And in this linſey woolſey way, that would make a dog
Forget his dinner, or an old man fire
They rub out for their ranſoms: Amongſt the reſt,
There is a little Boy rob'd, a fine child,
It ſeems a Page: I muſt confeſſe my pitty
(As 'tis a hard thing in a man of my place)
To ſhew compaſſion, ſtir'd at him; ſo finely
And without noyſe he carrys his afflictions,
And looks as if he had but dreamt of looſing.
sp.stage: Enter Host and Leocadia, and others as rob'd.
sp.l: This boy's the glory of this robbery,
The reſt but ſhame the action: now ye may hear 'em.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Come lads, 'tis holy-day: hang clothes, 'tis hot,
And ſweating agues are abroad.
It ſeems ſo;
For we have met with rare Phiſitians
To cure us of that mallady.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Fine footing,
Light and deliver: now my boys: Maſter Fryer,
How do's your holineſſe, bear up man; what
A cup of neat ſack now and a toaſt: ha, Fryer,
A warm plaiſter to your belly Father,
There were a bleſſing now.

sp.speaker: Fryer.
sp.l: Ye ſay your mind Sir.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Where my fine Boy: my poynter.

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: Ther's the wonder.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: A rank whore ſcratch their ſides till the pox follow
For robbing thee, thou haſt a thouſand ways
To rob thy ſelf boy, dyce, and a chamber devill.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Ye are deceiv'd Sir.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: And thy Maſter too Boy.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: A ſweet fac'd Boy indeed: what rogues were theſe?
What barbarous brutiſh ſlaves to ſtrip this beauty?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Come hither my boy: alas! he's cold, mine Hoſt,
We muſt intreat your Cloak.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Can ye intreat it.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: We do preſume ſo much, you have other gar|ments.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Will you intreat thoſe too?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Your Mule muſt too,
To the next town, you ſay 'tis neer; in pity
You cannot ſee this poor Boy periſh.
I know ye have a better ſoul, we'l ſatisfie ye.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: 'Tis a ſtrange fooliſh trick I have, but I cannot help it,
I am ever cozen'd with mine own commendations;
It is determin'd then I ſhall be robb'd too.
To make up vantage to this dozen: here Sir,
Heaven has provided ye a ſimple garment
To ſet ye off: pray keep it hanſomer
Then you kept your own, and let me have it render'd,
Bruſh'd, and diſcreetly folded.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: I thank ye Sir.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Who wants a doblet?
I.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Where will you have it?
From you Sir, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Oh, there's the poynt Sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: My honeſt friends, I am ſorry for your fortunes,
But that's but poor relief; here are ten Duckets,
And to your diſtribution holy Sir,
I render 'em: and let it be your care
To ſe 'em, as your wants are, well divided.

sp.speaker: Hoſ.
sp.l: Plain dealing now my friends: and Father Fryer,
Set me the ſadle right; no wringing Fryer,
Nor tithing to the Church, theſe are no duties;
Scowre me your conſcience, if the Devill tempt ye
Off with your cord, and ſwing him.

sp.speaker: Fry.
sp.l: Ye ſay well Sir.

sp.speaker: all.
sp.l: Heaven keep your goodneſſe.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Peace keep you, farewell friends

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Farewell light horſe-men. Exit the rob'd.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Which way travell you Sir.

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: To the next town.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Do you want any thing.

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: Only diſcretion to travell at good houres,
And ſome warm meat to moderate this matter,
For I am moſt outragious cruell hungry

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: I have a ſtomach too ſuch as it is
Would poſe a right good paſty, I thank heaven for't.

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: Cheeſ that would break the teeth of a new hand-ſaw,
I could endure now like an Eaſtrich, or ſalt beeffe
That Ceſar left in pickell.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Take no care,
Wee'l have meat for you and enough: I th' mean time
Keep you the horſe way leſt the fellow miſſe us,
We'l meet ye at the end o'th wood.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Make haſt then.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: My pretty Sir, till your neceſſities
Be full ſupplied, ſo pleaſe you truſt our friendſhips,
We muſt not part.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Ye have pull'd a charge upon ye,
Yet ſuch a one, as ever ſhall be thankfull.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Ye have ſaid enough: may I be bold to ask ye,
What Province you were bred in? and of what parents?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Ye may Sir: I was born in Andoluzia,
My name Franciſco, ſon to Don Henriques
De Cardinas.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Our noble neighbour.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Son to Don Henriques:
I know the gentleman: and by your leave Sir,
I know he has no ſon.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: None of his own Sir,
Which makes him put that right upon his brother
Don Zanchio's children: one of which I am,
And therefore do not much err.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Still ye do Sir,
For neither has Don Zanchio any ſon;
A daughter, and a rare one is heire,
Which though I never was ſo bleſt to ſee,
Yet I have heard great good of.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Urge no further,
He is aſhamed, and bluſhes.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Sir,
If it might import you to conceal your ſelf,
I ask your mercy, I have been ſo curious:

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Alas! I muſt ask yours Sir: for theſe lies,
Yet they were uſefull ones; for by the claiming
Such noble parents, I beleev'd your bounties
Would ſhew more gracious: The plain truth is gentlemen,
I am Don Sanchios ſtewards ſon, a wild boy,
That for the fruits of his unhappineſſe,
Is faigne to ſeek the wars.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: This is a lie too.
If I have any ears.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Mark his language,
And ye ſhall find it of too ſweet a reliſh
For one of ſuch a breed: ile pawn my hand,
This is no boy.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: No boy? what would you have him?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: I know, no boy: I watcht how fearfully,
And yet how ſodainly he cur'd his lies,
The right wit of a woman: Now I am ſure.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What are ye ſure?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: That 'tis no boy: ile burn in't.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Now I conſider better, and take councell,
Methinks he ſhows more ſweetneſſe in that face,
Then his fears dare deliver.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: No more talk on't,
There hangs ſome great waight by it: ſoon at night
Ile tell ye more.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Come Sir, what ere you are
With us, embrace your liberty, and our helps
In any need you have.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: All my poor ſervice
Shall be at your command Sir, and my prayers.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Let's walke a pace; hunger will cut their throats els. Exeunt.

div.head: SCAENA TERTIA.
div.stage: Enter Rodorigo, Markantonio, and a Ship-maſter, two Chairs ſet out.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Call up the Maſter.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Here Sir. within.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Honeſt Maſter,
Give order all the Gallys with this tyde
Fall round, and neer upon us; that the next wind
We may waigh off together, and recover
The Port of Barcelona, without parting.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Your pleaſures done Sir. within.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Signior Markantonio,
Till meat be ready, let's ſit here and prepare
Our ſtomachs with diſcourſes.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: What you pleaſe Sir.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Pray ye anſwer me to this doubt.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: If I can Sir.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Why ſhould ſuch plants as you are, pleaſures chil|dren
That ow their bluſhing years to gentle objects,
Tenderly bred, and brought up in all fulneſſe,
Deſire the ſtubborn wars?

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: In thoſe 'tis wonder,
That make their eaſe their god, and nor their honour:
But noble Generall, my end is other,
Deſire of knowledge Sir, and hope of tying
Diſcretion to my time, which only ſhews me,
And not my years, a man, and makes that more.
Which we call handſome, the reſt is but boys beauty,
And with the boy conſum'd.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Ye argue well Sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Nor do I wear my youth, as they were breches
For object, but for uſe: my ſtrength for danger,
Which is the liberal part of man, not dalliance,
The wars muſt be my Miſtreſs Sir.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: O Signiour,
You'l find her a rough wench.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: When ſhe is won once,
She'l ſhow the ſweeter Sir.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: You can be pleas'd, though
Sometimes to take a tamer?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Tis a truth Sir,
So ſhe be handſom, and not ill condition'd.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: A Soldier ſhould not be ſo curious.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I can make ſhift with any for a heat Sir.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Nay, there you wrong your youth too: and however
You are pleas'd to appear to me, which ſhews wel Signior,
A tougher ſoul then your few years can teſtifie;
Yet my yong Sir, out of mine own experience
When my ſpring was, I am able to confute ye,
And ſay, y' had rather come to th' ſhock of eys,
And boldly march up to your Miſtriſs mouth,
Then to the Cannons.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: That's as their lading is Sir.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: There be Trenches
Fitter, and warmer for your years, and ſafer
Then where the bullet plays.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Ther's it I doubt Sir.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: You'l eaſily find that faith: But come, be liberal,
What kind of woman could you make beſt wars with?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: They are all but heavy marches.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Fy Marckantonio,
Beauty in no more reverence?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: In the Sex Sir,
I honor it, and next to honor, love it,
For there is only beauty; and that ſweetneſs
That was firſt meant for modeſty: ſever it
And put it in one woman, it appears not.
'Tis of too rare a nature, ſhe too groſs
To mingle with it.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: This is a meer hereſie.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Which makes 'em ever mending; for that gloſs
That coſens us for beauty, is but bravery,
An outward ſhew of things well ſet, no more,
For heavenly beauty, is as heaven it ſelf Sir,
Too excellent for object, and what is ſeen
Is but the vail then, airy clouds; grant this
It may be ſeen, 'tis but like ſtars in twinklings.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: 'Twas no ſmall ſtudy in their Libraries
Brought you to this experience: But what think ye
Of that fair red and white, which we call beauty?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why? 'tis our creature Sir, we give it 'em,
Becauſe we like thoſe colours, elſe 'tis certain
A blew face with a motley noſe would do it,
And be as great a beauty, ſo we lov'd it,
That we cannot give, which is only beauty,
Is a fair Mind.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: By this rule, all our choices
Are to no ends.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Except the dull end, Doing.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Then all to you ſeem equal?

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Very true Sir,
And that makes equal dealing: I love any
That's worth love.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: How long love ye Signiour?

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Till I have other buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Do you never
Love ſtedfaſtly one woman?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Tis a toyl Sir
Like riding in one rode perpetually,
It offers no variety.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Right youth,
He muſt needs make a Soldier; nor do you think
One woman, can love one man.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes that may be,
Though it appear not often; they are things ignorant,
And therefore apted to that ſuperſtition
Of doting fondneſs; yet of late years Signior,
That worlds well mended with 'em, fewer are found now
That love at length, and to the right mark, all
Stir now as the time ſtirs; fame and faſhion
Are ends they aim at now, and to make that love
That wiſer ages held ambition;
They that cannot reach this, may love by Index;
By every days ſurveying who beſt promiſes,
Who has done beſt, who may do, and who mended
May come to do again: who appears neateſt
Either in new ſtampt cloths, or curteſies,
Done but from hand to mouth neither; nor love they theſe things
Longer then new are making, nor that ſucceſſion
Beyond the next fair feather: Take the City,
There they go to't by gold waight, no gain from 'em
All they can work by fire and water to 'em,
Profit is all they point at: if there be love
'Tis ſhew'd ye by ſo dark a light, to bear out
The bracks, and old ſtains in it, that ye may purchaſe
French velvet better cheap: all loves are endleſs.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Faith, if ye have a Miſtreſs, would ſhe heard you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Twere but the ventring of my place, or ſwearing
I meant it but for argument, as Schoolmen
Diſpute high queſtions.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: What a world is this
When young men dare determine what thoſe are?
Age and the beſt experience ne'r could aim at.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: They were thick ey'd then Sir; now the print is bigger,
And they may read their fortunes without ſpectacles.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Did you ne'r love?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Faith yes, once after ſupper,
And the fit held till midnight.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Hot, or ſhaking.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: To ſay true, both.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: How did ye rid it?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Thus Sir,
I laid my hand upon my heart, and bleſt me,
And then ſaid over certain charms I had learn'd
Againſt mad dogs, for love, and they are all one;
Laſt thought upon a windmill, and ſo ſlept,
And was well ever after.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: A rare Phyſitian,
What would your practiſe gain ye?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: The wars ended,
I mean to uſe my heart, and have theſe fools
Cut in the head like Cats, to ſave the Kingdom,
Another Inquiſition.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: So old a Soldier.
Out of the wars, I never knew yet practiſed.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I ſhall mend every day; But noble General,
Believe this, but as this you nam'd diſcourſes.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: O ye are a cunning Gamſter.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Mirths and toys
To coſen time withall, for O my troth Sir,
I can love; I think, well too; well enough
And think as wel of women as they are,
Pretty fantaſtick things, ſome more regardful,
And ſome few worth a ſervice: I am ſo honeſt,
I with 'em all in heaven, and you know hard Sir
'Twill be to get in there with their great farthingalls.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Well Marckantonio, I would not looſe thy company
For the beſt. Galley I command.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Faith Generall,
If theſe diſcourſeſ pleaſe ye, I ſhall fit ye
Once every day. knock within.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Thou canſt not pleaſe me better: hark, they call
Below to Didner: ye are my Cabbin gueſt,
My boſom's, ſo you pleaſe Sir.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Your poor Servant. Exeunt.

div.head: Scena quarta.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Let 'em have meat enough woman, half a hen;
There be old rotten pilchers, put 'em off too,
'Tis but a little new anoynting of 'em,
And a ſtrong onyon, that confounds the ſtink.

sp.speaker: Hoſteſſ.
sp.l: They call for more Sir.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Knock a dozen eggs down,
But then beware your wenches.

sp.speaker: Hoſteſſ.
sp.l: More then this too?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Worts, worts, and make 'em porridg: pop 'em up
But they ſhall pay for Cullyſes.

sp.speaker: Hoſteſſ.
sp.l: All this is nothing;
They call for kid and partridg.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Well remembred,
Where's the half Falconers dog he left?

sp.speaker: Hoſteſſ.
sp.l: It ſtinks Sir,
Paſt all hope that way.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Run it o're with garlick,
And make a Roman diſh on't.

sp.speaker: Hosteſſ.
sp.l: Pray ye be patient,
And get proviſion in; theſe are fine Gentlemen,
And liberal Gentlemen; they have unde quare
No mangey Muleters, nor pinching Poſts
That feed upon the parings of musk-millions
And radiſhes, as big and tough as rafters:
Will ye be ſtirring in this buſineſs? here's your brother
Mine old Hoſt of Oſſuva, as wiſe as you are,
That is, as knaviſh; if ye put a trick,
Take heed he do not find it.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Ile be wagging.

sp.speaker: Hoſteſſ.
sp.l: 'Tis for your own commodity: why wenches.
Anon for ſooth. within.

sp.speaker: Hoſteſſ.
sp.l: Who makes a fire there? and who gets in water?
Let Oliver go to the Juſtice, and beſeech his worſhip
We may have two ſpits going; and do you here Druce,
Let him invite his worſhip, and his wives worſhip,
To the left meat to morrow. Enter Bayliff.

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: Where's the Kitchen?

sp.speaker: Hosteſſ.
sp.l: Even at the next door Signior: what old Don?
We meet but ſeldom.

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: Prethee be patient Hoſteſs,
And tell me where the meat is.

sp.speaker: Hoſteſſ.
sp.l: Faith Master Bayly,
How have ye done? and how man?

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: Good ſweet Hoſteſs,
What ſhall we have to dinner?

sp.speaker: Hosteſſ.
sp.l: How do's your woman,
And a fine woman ſhe is and a good woman,
Lord, how you bear your years?

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: Is't veal, or mutton,
Beef, bacon, pork, kid, pheaſant, or all theſe,
And are they ready all?

sp.speaker: Hoſteſſ.
sp.l: The hours that have been
Between us two, the merry hours: Lord!

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: Hoſteſs,
Dear Hoſteſs do but hear; I am hungry.

sp.speaker: Hoſteſſ.
sp.l: Ye are merrily diſpos'd Sir.

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: Monſtrous hungry,
And hungry after much meat, I have brought hither
Right worſhipful to pay the reckoning,
Money enough too with 'em, deſire enough
To have the beſt meat, and of that enough too:
Come to the point ſweet wench, and ſo I kiſs thee.

sp.speaker: Hoſteſſ.
sp.l: Ye ſhall have any thing, and inſtantly
Ere you can lick your ears, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: Portly meat,
Bearing ſubſtantial stuff, and fit for hunger:
I do beſeech ye Hoſteſs firſt, then ſome light garniſh,
Two pheaſants in a diſh, if ye have leverits,
Rather for way of ornament, then appetite
They may be look'd upon, or larks: for fiſh,
As there is no great need, ſo I woul I not wiſh ye
To ſerve above four diſhes, but thoſe full ones;
Ye have no cheeſe of Parma?

sp.speaker: Hoſteſſ.
sp.l: Very old Sir.

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: The leſs will ſerve us, ſome ten pound,

sp.speaker: Hoſteſſ.
sp.l: Alas Sir,
We have not half theſe dainties.

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: Peace good Hoſteſs,
And make us hope ye have.

sp.speaker: Hosteſſ.
sp.l: Ye ſhall have all Sir,

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: That may be got for money.

div.stage: Enter Diego the Hoſt, and a Boy.

sp.speaker: 1. Hoſt. Diego.
sp.l: Where's your Maſter?
Bring me your Maſter boy: I muſt have liquor
Fit for the Mermedons; no daſhing now child,
No conjurings by candle light, I know all;
Strike me the oldeſt Sack, a piece that carries
Point blank to this place boy, and batters; Hoſteſs,
I kiſs thy hands through which many a round reckoning
And things of moment have had motion.

sp.speaker: Hoſteſſ.
sp.l: Still mind old Brother.

sp.speaker: 1. Hoſt Dei.
sp.l: Set thy Seller open,
For I muſt enter, and advance my colours
I have brought the Dons indeed wench, Dons with duckets,
And thoſe Dons muſt have dainty wine, pure Bacchus
That bleeds the life blood: what is your cure ended?

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: We ſhall have meat man.

sp.speaker: 1. Hoſt Die.
sp.l: Then we ſhallhave wine man,
And wine upon wine, cut and drawn with wine.

sp.speaker: Hoſteſſ.
sp.l: Ye ſhall have all, and more then all.

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: All, well then.

sp.speaker: 1. Host Die.
sp.l: Away, about your buſineſs, you with her
For old acquaintance ſake, to ſtay your ſtomach Exit Ho|ſteſſe and Bayliffe.
And Boy, be you my guide ad inferos,
For I will make a full deſcent in equipage.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Ile ſhew you rare wine.

sp.speaker: 1. Host Die.
sp.l: Stinging geer.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Divine Sir.

sp.speaker: 1. Hoſt Die.
sp.l: O divine boy, march, march my child, rare wine boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: As in Spain Sir.

sp.speaker: 1. Hoſt Die.
sp.l: Old, and strong too,
O my fine Boy, clear too?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: As chriſtal Sir, and ſtrong as truth.

sp.speaker: 1. Hoſt Die.
sp.l: Away boy,
I am enamour'd, and I long for Dalligance,
Stay no where child, not for thy fathers bleſſing,
I charge thee not to ſave thy ſiſters honour,
Nor to cloſe thy dams eys were ſhe a dying,
Till we arrive; and for thy recompence
I will remember thee in my Will.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Ye have ſaid Sir. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: MINE Hoſt, is that apperrel got ye ſpoke of?
Ye ſhall have ready money.

sp.speaker: 2. Hoſt.
sp.l: 'Tis come in Sir, he has it on Sir,
And I think't will be fit, and o' my credit
'Twas never worn but once Sir, and for neceſſity
Pawnd to the man I told ye of.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Pray bargain for it,
And I will be the pay-maſter.

sp.speaker: 2. Hoſt.
sp.l: I will Sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: And let our meat be ready when you pleaſe,
I mean as ſoon.

sp.speaker: 2. Hoſt.
sp.l: It ſhall be preſently.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How far ſtands Barcelona?

sp.speaker: 2. Hoſt.
sp.l: But two leagues off Sir,
You may be there by three a clock.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I am glad on't. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Signior Franciſco why I draw you hither
To this remote place, marvel not, for truſt me
My innocence yet never knew ill dealing,
And as ye have a noble temper, ſtart not
Into offence, at any thing my knowledg,
And for your ſpecial good, would be inform'd of,
Nor think me vainly curious.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Worthy Sir,
The courteſies you and your noble Brother
Even then when few men find the way to do 'em,
I mean in want, ſo freely ſhowrd upon me,
So truly and ſo timely miniſter'd,
Muſt if I ſhould ſuſpect thoſe minds that made 'em,
Either proclaim me an unworthy taker,
Or worſe, a baſe believer; Speak your mind Sir
Freely, and what you pleaſe, I am your Servant.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Then my yong Sir, know ſince our firſt acquaintance
Induc'd by circumſtances that deceive not
To clear ſome doubts I have; nay bluſh not Signior,
I have beheld ye narrowly; more bluſhes!
Sir, ye give me ſo much light, I find ye
A thing confeſt already; yet more bluſhes?
You would ill cover an offence might ſink ye
That cannot hide your ſelf; why do ye ſhake ſo?
I mean no trouble to ye; this fair hand
Was never made for hardneſs, nor thoſe eys.
Come do not hide 'em, for rough objects, hark ye,
Ye have betrayd your ſelf, that ſigh confirms me;
An other? and a third to? then I ſee
Theſe Boys clothes do but pinch ye, come be liberal,
Ye have found a friend that has found you, diſguiſe not
That loaden ſoul that labors to be open:
Now you muſt weep, I know it, for I ſee
Your eys down laden to the lids, another
Manifeſt token that my doubts are perfect;
Yet I have found a greater; till me this
Why were theſe holes left open, there was an error,
A foul one my Franciſco, have I caught ye?
O pretty Sir, the cuſtom of our Country
Allows men none in this place: Now the ſhowr comes.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: O Signior Theodoro.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: This ſorrow ſhews ſo ſweetly
I cannot chuſe but keep it company:
Take truce and ſpeak Sir: and I charge your goodneſs
by all thoſe perfect hopes that point at vertue
By that remembrance theſe fair tears are ſhed for,
If any ſad miſ-fortune have thus form'd ye,
That either care or counſel may redeem,
Pain, purſe, or any thing within the power
And honor of free Gentlemen, reveal it,
And have our labors.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: I have found ye noble
And ye ſhall find me true; your doubts are certain,
Nor dare I more diſſemble; I am a woman,
The great example of a wretched woman;
Here you muſt give me leave to ſhew my Sex;
And now to make ye know how much your credit
Has won upon my ſoul, ſo it pleaſe your patience,
Ile tell you my unfortunate ſad ſtory.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Sit down and ſay on Lady.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: I am born Sir
Of good and honeſt parents, rich, and noble,
And not to lye, the daughter of Don Zanchio,
If my unhappy fortune have not loſt me:
My name cal'd Leocadia, even the ſame
Your worthy brother did the ſpecial honor
To name for beautiful; and without pride
I have been often made believe ſo Signior;
But thats impertinent: Now to my ſorrows;
Not far from us a Gentleman of worth,
A neighbor and a noble viſitor,
Had his aboad; who often met my Father
In gentle ſports of chaſe, and river hawking,
In courſe and riding, and with him often brought
A Son of his, a young and hopeful Gentleman,
Nobly train'd up, in years fit for affection,
A ſprighly man, of underſtanding excellent,
Of ſpeech, and civill 'havior, no leſs powerful;
And of all parts, elſe my eys lyed, abundant:
We grew acquainted, and from that acquaintance
Neerer into affection; from affection
Into belief.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Well.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Then we durſt kiſs.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Go forward.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: But O man, man, unconſtant, careleſs man,
O ſubtile man, how many are thy miſchiefs?
O Marck-antonio, I may curſe thoſe kiſſes.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: What did you call him Lady?

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Mark-antonio,
The name to me of miſery.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Pray foreward.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: From theſe we bred deſires Sir: but loſe me heaven
If mine were luſtful.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: I believe.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: This neerneſs
Made him importunate: When to ſave mine honor
Love having full poſſeſſion of my powers,
I got a contract from him.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Sealed?

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: And ſworn too:
Which ſince for ſome offence heaven laid upon me
I loſt among my moneys in the robbery,
The loſs that makes me pooreſt: this won from him
Fool that I was, and too too credulous,
I pointed him a by-way to my chamber
The next night at an hour.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Pray stay there Lady:
And when the night came, came he, kept he touch with ye?
Be not ſo ſhamefaſt: had he both your wiſhes?
Tell me, and tell me true, did he injoy ye,
Were ye in one anothers arms, abed? the Contract
Confirm'd in full joys there? did he lie with ye?
Anſwer to that; ha? did your father know this,
The good old man, or kindred privy to't?
And had ye their conſents? did that nights promiſe
Make ye a Mother?

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Why do you aſk ſo neerly?
Good Sir, do's it concern you any thing?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: No Lady,
Only the pitty why you ſhould be uſed ſo,
A little ſtirs me, but did he keep his promiſe?

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: No, no Signior,
Alas he never came nor never meant it,
My love was fool'd, time numbred to no end,
My expectation ſlouted, and gheſs you Sir,
What dor unto a doating Maid this was,
What a baſe breaking off.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: All's well then Lady;
Go forward in your Story.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Not only fail'd Sir
Which is a curſe in love, and may he find it
When his affections are full wing'd, and ready
To ſtoop upon the quarry, then when all
His full hopes are in's arms: not only thus Sir
But more injurious, faithleſs, treacherous,
Within two days fame gave him far remov'd
With a new love, which much againſt my conſcience
But more againſt my cauſe, which is my hell
I muſt confeſs a fair one, a right fair one,
Indeed of admirable ſweetneſs, Daughter
Unto another of our noble neighbors
The thief cal'd Theodoſia; whoſe perfections
I am bound to ban for ever, curſe to wrinckles,
As heaven I hope will make 'em ſoon; and aches,
For they have rob'd me poor unhappy wench
Of all, of all Sir, all that was my glory
And left me nothing but theſe tears, and travel:
Upon this certain news, I quit my Father
And if you be not milder in conſtruction
I fear mine honor too; and like a Page
Stole to Oſſuna: from that place to Civill,
From thence to Barcellona I was travelling
When you o'er-took my miſery, in hope to hear of
Gallies bound up for Italy; for never
Will I leave off the ſearch of this bad man
This filcher of affections, this love Pedler,
Nor ſhall my curſes ceaſe to blaſt her beauties
And make her name as wandring as her nature
Till ſtanding face to face before their luſts
I call heavens juſtice down.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: This ſhows too angry
Nor can it be her fault ſhe is belov'd,
If I give meat, muſt they that eat it ſurfeit?

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: She loves again Sir, there's the miſchief of it
And in deſpight of me to drown my bleſſings
Which ſhe ſhall dearly know.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Ye are too violent.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: She has Devils in her eys, to whoſe devotion
He offers all his ſervice.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Who can ſay
But ſhe may be forſaken too? he that once wanders
From ſuch a perfect ſweetneſs, as you promiſe
Has he not ſtill the ſame rule to deceive?

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: No, no they are together, love together
Paſt all deceipt of that ſide; ſleep together,
Live, and delight together, and ſuch deceipt
Give me in a wild deſert.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: By your leave Lady
I ſee no honor in this cunning.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Honor?
True, none of her part, honor, ſhe deſerves none,
'Tis ceas'd with wandering Ladies ſuch as ſhe is,
So bold and impudent.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: I could be angry
Extreamly angry now beyond my nature
And 'twere not for my pitty: what a man
is this to do theſe wrongs: believe me Lady
I know the maid, and know ſhe is not with him.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: I would you knew ſhe were in heaven.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: And ſo well know her
That l think you are cozend.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: So I ſay Sir.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: I mean in her behaviour
For truſt my faith ſo much I dare adventure for her credit
She never yet delighted to do wrong:

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: How can ſhe then delight in him; dare ſhe think
Be what ſhe will, as excellent as Angels
