My love ſo fond, my wiſhes ſo indulgent
That I muſt take her prewnings; ſtoop at that
She has tyr'd upon: No Sir, I hold my beauty
Waſh but theſe ſorrows from it; of a ſparkle
As right and rich as hers, my means as equal,
My youth as much unblown: and for our worths
And waight of vertue.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Do not task her ſo far.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: By heaven ſhe is cork, and clouds, light, light ſir, vapor
But I ſhall find her out, with all her witchcrafts,
Her paintings, and her powncings: for 'tis art
And only art preſerves her, and meer ſpels
That work upon his powers: let her but ſhew me
A ruin'd cheek like mine, that holds his colour
And writes but ſixteen years in ſpight of ſorrows
An unbathed body, ſmiles, that give but ſhadows
And wrinckle not the face: beſides ſhe is little
A demy dame that, that makes no object.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Nay,
Then I muſt ſay you err: for credit me
I think ſhe is taller then your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Why let her
It is not that ſhall mate me: I but ask
My hands may reach unto her.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Gentle Lady
'Tis now ill time of further argument,
For I perceive your anger voyd of councel,
Which I could wiſh more temperate.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Pray forgive me
If I have ſpoken uncivilly: they that look on
See more than we that play: and I beſeech ye
Impute it loves offence, not mine; whoſe torments,
If you have ever lov'd, and found my croſſes
You muſt confeſſe are ſeldom ty'd to patience,
Yet I could wiſh I had ſaid leſſe.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: No harm then;
Ye have made a full amends; our Company
You may command, ſo pleaſe you in your travels
With all our faith and furtherance; let it be ſo.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Ye make too great an offer.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Then it ſhal be
Go in and reſt your ſelf, our wholſom dyet
Will be made ready ſtraight: But hark ye Lady
One thing I muſt entreat, your leave, and ſufferance
That theſe things may be open to my Brother
For more reſpect and honour.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Do your pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: And do not change this habit by no means
Unleſs ye change your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Which muſt not yet be.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: It carries ye concealed and ſafe.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: I am counſel'd. Exit.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What's done?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Why all we doubted; 'tis a woman,
And of a noble ſtrain too, gheſſe.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I cannot.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: You have heard often of her.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Stay I think not.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Indeed ye have; 'tis the fair Leocadia
Daughter unto Don Zanchio, our noble neighbor.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nay?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: 'Tis ſhe Sir o' my credit.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Leocadia,
Piſh Leocadia, it muſt not be.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: It muſt be, or be nothing.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Pray give me leave to wonder, Leocadia?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: The very ſame.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: The damſel Leocadia
I gheſt it was a woman, and a fair one
I ſee it through her ſhape, tranſparant plain
But that it ſhould be ſhe; tell me directly.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: By heavens 'tis ſhee.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: By heaven then 'tis a ſweet one.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: That's granted too.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: But heark ye, heark ye Siſter,
How came ſhe this diſguis'd?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Ile tell you that too
As I came on the ſelf-ſame ground, ſo us'd too.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: By the ſame man?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: The ſame too.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: As I live
You lovers have fine fancies,
Wonderous fine ones.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Pray heaven you never make one.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Faith I know not,
But in that mind I am, I had rather cobble,
'Tis a more Chriſtian trade: pray tell me one thing
Are not you two now monſtrous jealous
Of one another?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: She is much of me
And has rayl'd at me moſt unmercifully
And to my face, and o' my conſcience
Had ſhe but known me, either ſhe or I
Or both, had parted with ſtrange faces
She was in ſuch a fury.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Leocadia?
Do's ſhe ſpeak hanſomly?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Wondrous wel Sir
And all ſhe do's becomes her, even her anger.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How ſeem'd ſhe when you found her?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Had you ſeen
How ſweetly fearfull her pretty ſelf
Betray'd her ſelf, how neat her ſorrow ſhow'd,
And in what hanſom phraſe ſhee put her story,
And as occaſion ſtir'd her how ſhe ſtarted
Though roughly, yet moſt aptly into anger
You would have wonder'd.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Do's ſhe know ye?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: No.
Nor muſt not by no means.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How ſtands your difference?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Ile tell ye that ſome fitter time, but truſt me
My Marck-antonio has too much to anſwer.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: May I take knowledge of her?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Yes ſhe is willing.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Pray uſe her as ſhe is, with all reſpects then,
For ſhe is a woman of a noble breeding.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Ye ſhal not find me wanting.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Which way bears ſhe?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Our way, and to our end.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I am glad on't; heark ye,
She keeps her ſhape? Enter Leocadia.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Yes, and I think by this time
Has mew'd her old.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: She is here: by heaven a rare one,
An admirable ſweet one, what an eye
Of what a full command ſhe bears, how gracious
All her aſpect ſhows; bleſs me from a feavor
I am not well o'th ſodain.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Noble friends
Your meat and all my ſervice waits upon ye.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Ye teach us manners Lady; all which ſervice
Muſt now be mine to you, and all to poor too;
Bluſh not, we know ye; for by all our faiths
With us your honor is in ſanctuary
And ever ſhal be.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: I do well beleeve it,
Will ye walk neerer Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Theo
sp.l: She ſhows ſtil fairer,
Yonger in every change, and clearer, neater;
I know not, I may fool my ſelf, and finely
Nouriſh a wolfe to eat my heart out; Certain
As ſhe appears now, ſhe appears a wonder,
A thing amazes me; what would ſhe do then
In womans helps, in ornaments apt for her
And deckings to her delicacy? without all doubt
She would be held a miracle; nor can I think
He has forſaken her: Say what ſhee pleaſe,
I know his curious eye, or ſay he had,
Put caſe he could be ſo boy-blind and fooliſh,
Yet ſtil I fear ſhe keeps the Contract with her
Not ſtolne as ſhe affirms, nor loſt by negligence,
She would looſe her ſelf firſt, 'tis her life, and there
All my hopes are diſpatch'd; O noble love
That thou couldſt be without this jealouſie,
Without this paſſion of the heart, how heavenly
Would thou appear upon us? Come what may come
Ile ſee the end on't: and ſince chance has caſt her
Naked into my refuge, all I can
She freely ſhal command, except the man. Exit.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Don Pedro, do you think aſſuredly
The Gallyes will come round to Barcellona
Within theſe two dayes?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Without doubt.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: And think ye
He will be with 'em certainly?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: He is ſir
I ſaw him at their ſetting off.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Muſt they needs
Touch there for water as you ſay?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: They muſt ſir
And for freſh meat too: few or none go by it
Beſide ſo great a Fleet muſt needs want trimming
If they have met with fowle ſeas, no harbour
On this ſide, Spain, is able without danger
To moore 'em, but that haven.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Are the warrs
His only end?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: So he profeſſes.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Bears he
Any command amongſt 'em?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Good regard
With all; which quickly will prefer him.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Pray Sir tell me,
And as you are a gentleman be liberal.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I will Sir, and moſt true.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Who ſaw ye with him?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: None but things like himſelf; yong ſoldiers
And gentlemen deſirous to ſeek honor.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Was there no woman there, nor, none diſguis'd
That might be thought a woman in his language?
Did he not let ſlip ſomething of ſuſpition
Touching that wanton way.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Beleeve me Sir
I neither ſaw, nor could ſuſpect that face
That might be doubted womans, yet I am ſure
Aboard him I ſee all that paſt, and 'tis impoſſible
Among ſo many high ſet bloods there ſhould be
A woman, let her cloſe her ſelf within a cockle,
But they would open her, he muſt not love
Within that place alone, and therefore ſurely
He would not be ſo fooliſh, had he any,
To truſt her there; for his diſcourſe, 'twas ever
About his buſineſs, war, or mirth to make us
Reliſh a Can of wine wel; when he ſpoke private
'T was only the remembrance of his ſervice,
And hope of your good prayers for his health Sir,
And ſo I gave him to the ſeas.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I thank ye,
And now am ſatisfied, and to prevent
Suſpitions that may nouriſh dangers Signior,
For I have told you how the mad Alphenſo
Chafes like a Stag i'th toyl, and bends his fury
'Gainſt all, but his own ignorance; I am determin'd
For peace ſake and the preſervation
Of my yet untouch'd honor, and his cure
My ſelf to ſeek him there, and bring him back
As teſtimony of an unſought injurie
By either of our actions; That the world
And he if he have reaſon, may ſee plainly
Opinion is no perfect guide; nor all fames
Founders of truths: In the mean time this courteſie
I muſt entreat of you Sir, Be my ſelf here
And as my ſelf command my family.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Ye lay too much truſt on me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: 'Tis my love Sir,
I wil not be long from ye; if this queſtion
Chance to be call'd upon ere my return
I leave your care to anſwer; So farewell Sir.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Ye take a wiſe way; All my beſt endeavors
Shal labor in your abſence; peace go with ye. Exit Leo.
A noble honeſt gentleman, free hearted
And of an open faith, much loving, and much loved,
And father of that goodneſſe only malice
Can truly ſtir againſt; what dare befall
Till his return Ile anſwer. Exit Ped.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Walk off Sirha
But keep your ſelf within my call?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: I will Sir.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: And ſtir my horſe for taking cold: within there,
Hoa people; you that dwel there, my brave Signior
What are ye all a ſleep? is't that time with ye?
Ile ring a little lowder.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Sir who ſeek ye?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Not you Sir; Where's your Maſter?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I ſerve no man
In way of pay ſir.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Where's the man o'th houſe then?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: What would you have with him Sir?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Do you ſtand here Sir
To ask men queſtions when they come?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I would ſir
Being his friend, and hearing ſuch allarums
Know how men come to viſit him.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Ye ſhall ſir,
Pray tell his mightineſs here is a gentleman
By name Alphonſo, would entreat his conference
About affairs of ſtate ſir, are ye anſwer'd?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I muſt be ſir.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Stay, ſet me down, ſtay Signior,
You muſt ſtay, and ye ſhall ſtay.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Meaning me ſir?

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Yes you Sir, you I mean, I mean you.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Well Sir,
Why ſhould I ſtay?

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: There's reaſon.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Reaſon Sir?

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: I reaſon ſir
My wrong is greateſt, and I will be ſerv'd firſt,
Call out the man of fame?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: How ſerv'd ſir?

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Thus ſir.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: But not before me.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Before all the world ſir
As my caſe ſtands.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I have loſt a daughter ſir.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: I have loſt another worth five ſcore of her ſir.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Ye muſt not tel me ſo.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: I have, and heark ye?
Make it up five ſcore more: Call out the fellow,
And ſtand you by ſir.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: This is the mad morriſſe.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: And I ſtand by?

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: I ſay ſtand by, and do it.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Stand by among thy lungs.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Turn preſently
And ſay thy prayers, thou art dead.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I ſcorn thee
And ſcorn to ſay my prayers more then thou do●ſt,
Mine is the moſt wrong, and my daughter deereſt
And mine ſhal firſt be righted.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Shal be righted.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: A third may live I ſee, pray hear me gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Shalbe.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I, ſhal be righted.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Now?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Now.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Before I ſtir.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Before me.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Before any.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Doſt thou conſider what thou ſayſt? haſt thou friends here
Able to quench my anger, or perſwade me
After I have beaten thee into one main bruiſt
And made thee ſpend thy ſtate in rotten apples,
Thou canſt at length be quiet, ſhal I kil thee
Divide thee like a rotten Pumpion,
And leave thee ſtincking to poſterity,
Ther's not the leaſt blow I ſhall give; but do's this
Urge me no further: I am firſt.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Ile hang firſt.
No goodman glory, 'tis not your bravado's,
Your punctuall honor, nor ſoldadoſhip.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Set me a little neerer.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Let him ſally.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Lin'd with your quircks of carriage and diſcretion
Can blow me off my purpoſe. Wher's your credit
With all your ſchool points now? your decent arguing
And apt time for performing: where are theſe toys,
Theſe wiſe ways, and moſt honourable courſes,
To take revenge? how dar'ſt thou talk of killing,
Or think of drawing any thing but ſquirts
When letchery has dry founderd thee?

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Neerer yet,
That I may ſpit him down: thou look'ſt like a man.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I would be thought ſo Sir.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Prethee do but take me,
And fling me upon that Puppy.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Do for heavens ſake,
And ſee but how ile hug him.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Yet take warning.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Faith gentlemen, this is a needleſſe quarrell.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: And do you deſire to make one?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: As a friend Sir,
To tell you all this anger is but loſt Sir,
For Leonardo is from home.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: No, no Sir.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Indeed he is.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Where dare he be, but here Sir,
When men are wrong'd, and come for ſatisfactions.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: It ſeems he has done none Sir, for his buſineſſe
Cleer of thoſe cares, hath carried him for ſometime
To Barcelona; if he had been guilfy,
I know he would have ſtaid, and cleer'd all difference
Either by free confeſſion, or his ſword.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: This muſt not be.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Sure, as I live, it is Sir.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Sure, as we all live,
He's run away for ever: Barcelona,
Why? 'tis the key for Italy, from whence
He ſtole firſt hither.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: And having found his knaveries
Too groſſe to be forgiven, and too open,
He has found the ſame way back again: I beleeve too
The good graſſe gentleman, for his own eaſe,
Has taken one oth'Pillyes: Is not his ſtuffe ſold.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I fear his worſhips ſhoos too; to eſcape us,
I do not think he has a diſh within dores,
A louſe left of his linnage.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Ye are too wide Sir.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Or one poor wooden ſpoon,

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Come in and ſee Sir.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Ile ſee his houſe on fire firſt.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Then be pleas'd Sir
To give better cenſure.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: I will after him,
And ſearch him like conceal'd land; but ile have him,
And though I find him in his ſhrift, ile kill him.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Ile bear ye company.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Pray have a care then,
A moſt eſpeciall care, indeed a fear,
Ye do not anger me.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I will obſerve ye,
And if I light upon him hanſomly.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Kill but a peece of him, leave ſome Alphonſo
For your poor friends.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I fear him not for all this.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Shall we firſt go home,
For it may prove a voyage, and diſpoſe
Of things there; heaven knows what may follow.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: No,
Ile kill him in this ſhirt I have on: let things
Govern themſelves, I am maſter of my honor
At this time, and no more; let wife, and land,
Lie lay till I return.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I ſay amen to't:
But what care for our monies?

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: I will not ſpend
Above three ſhillings, till his head be here,
Foure is too great a ſum for all his fortunes.
Come take me up inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Farewell to you Sir,
And if your friend be in a featherbed,
Sow'd up to ſhrowd his fears, tell him 'tis folly,
For no courſe but his voluntary hanging
Can get our pardons. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Theſe I think would be
Offence enough, if their own indiſcretions
Would ſuffer 'em: two of the old ſeditions,
When they want enemies, they are their own foes:
Were they a little wiſer, I ſhould doubt 'em:
Till when ile ne'r break ſleep, nor ſuffer hunger
For any harm he ſhall receive: For 'tis as eaſie
If he be guilty, to turn theſe two old men
Upon their own throats, and look on, and live ſtill.
As 'tis to tell five pound: a great deal ſooner,
And ſo ile to my meat, and then to hawking. Exit.

div.head: SCAENA I.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Sir, this is complement; I pray you leave me.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Sir, is it not?

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Why? I would only ſee the Town.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: And only that I come to ſhew you.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Which I can ſee without you.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: So you may
Plainly, not ſafely: For ſuch difference
As you have ſeen betwixt the ſea and earth
When waves riſe high, and land would beat 'em back
As fearfull of Invaſion; ſuch we find
When we land here at Barcelona.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Beſides our Generall of the Gallyes, fearing
Your haſty nature, charg'd me not return
Without you ſafe.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: O Sir, that Rodorigo
Is noble, and he do's miſtake my temper.
There is not in the world, a mind leſſe apt
To conceive wrongs, or do 'em; ha's he ſeen me
In all this voyage, in the which he pleaſes
To call me friend, let ſlip a haſty word?
'S'light Sir: yonder is a Lady vaild,
For properneſſe, beyond compariſon,
And ſure her face is like the reſt: we'l ſee't.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Why? you are haſty Sir already: know you
What 'tis you go about.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Yes, I would ſee
The womans face.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: By heaven you ſhall not do't: Iob. Eacon ready to ſhool off a Piſtol.
You do not know the cuſtome of the place:
To draw that curtain here, though ſhe were mean,
Is mortall.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Is it? earth muſt come to earth
At laſt, and by my troth, ile ity it Sir.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Then I muſt hold you faſt. By all the faith
That can be plac'd in man, 'tis an attempt
More dangerous then death: 'tis death and ſhame:
I know the Lady well.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Is ſhe a Lady?
I ſhall the more deſire to ſee her Sir.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: She is Alanſo's wife, the Governor,
A noble gentleman.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Then let me go,
If I can win her, you and I will govern
This Town Sir, fear it not, and we will alter
Theſe barbarous cuſtomes then; for every Lady
Shall be ſeen daily, and ſeen over too.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Come, do not jeſt, nor let your paſſions bear you
To ſuch wild enterpriſes: hold you ſtill,
For as I have a ſoul, you ſhall not do't.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: She is a Lady of unblemiſhd'd fame, above.
And here to offer that affront, were baſe:
Hold on your way, and we will ſee the Town,
And overlook the Ladyes.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: I am ſchool'd,
And promiſe you I will: But good Sir, ſee,
Shee will paſſe by us now; I hope I may
Salute her thus far off.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: 'S foot, are you mad?
'Twill be as ill as th'other.

sp.speaker: 1. Attend.
sp.l: What's the matter?
What would that fellow have?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Good Sir forbear,

sp.speaker: 1. Atte.
sp.l: It ſeems you are new landed: would you beg
Any thing here?

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Yes Sir, all happineſſe
To that fair Lady, as I hope.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Marckantonio.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Her face, which needs no hiding: I would beg
A ſight of.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Now go on, for 'tis too late
To keep this from a tumult.

sp.speaker: 1. Attend.
sp.l: Sirrah, you
Shall ſee a fitter object for your eyes,
Then a fair Ladies face.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: For heavens ſake, raiſe not
A quarrell in the ſtreets for me.

sp.speaker: 1. Attend.
sp.l: Slip in then;
This is your door.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Will you needs quarrell then?

sp.speaker: 1. Attend.
sp.l: We muſt, or ſuffer
This outrage: is't not all your minds ſirs, ſpeak?

sp.speaker: all.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Then I do beſeech ye, let my Lord
Not think the quarrell about mee; for 'tis not. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: See, happly ſome of our Galley Soldiers
Are come a ſhore.

sp.speaker: 1. Attend.
sp.l: Come on Sir, you ſhall ſee
Faces enough.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Some one of you call to
Our Generall, the whole rore of the Towne
Comes in upon us.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: I have ſeen Sir bettet
Perhaps, then that was cover'd; and will yet
See that, or ſpoil yours. fight.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: On: why ſtart you back?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Alas Sir, they are fighting.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Let's begon,
See, ſee, a hanſome man ſtrook down.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Ho Generall,
Look out, Antonio is iti diſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Antonio?

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Antonio! 'tis he.

sp.speaker: Rod. within.
sp.l: Ho, Governor make a ſhot into the Town,
Ile part you: bring away Antonio a ſhot.
Into my Cabben. Exit Attendents and Townſmen.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I will do that office.
I fear It is the laſt, that I ſhall do him.

div.stage: Exit Soldiers and Gentlemen with Marckantonio.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: The laſt, why will he die?

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Since I have found him: happineſſe leave me,
When I leave him. Exit.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why Theodoſia?
My Siſter; wake: alas, I griev'd but now
To ſee the ſtreels ſo full; and now I grieve
To ſee 'em leſt ſo empty I could wiſh,
Tumult himſelf were here, that yet at leaſt
Amongſt the band, I might eſpie ſome face
So pale and fearfull, that would willingly
Embrace an arrand for a Cordiall,
Or Aquavitae, or a cup of ſack,
Or a Phiſitian. But to talk of theſe
She breaths: ſtand up, O Theodoſia,
Speak but as thou wert wont, give but a ſigh,
Which is but the moſt unhappy peece of life,
And I will ever after worſhip and build
Apply my ſelf to grief; prepare and build
Altars to ſorrow.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: O Philippo, help me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I do; theſe are my arms; Philippo's arms,
Thy Brothers arms that hola thee up.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: You help me
To life: but I would ſee Antonio
That's dead.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt ſee any thing; how doſt thou?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Better, I thank you.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why that's well: call up
Thy ſences, and uncloud thy cover'd ſpirits.
How now?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Recover'd: but Antonio,
Where is he?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: We will find him: art thou well?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Perfectly well, ſaving the miſſe of him;
And I do charge you here, by our allyance,
And by the love which would have been betwixt us,
Knew we no kindred; by that killing fear,
Mingled with twenty thouſand hopes and doubts,
Which you may think, plac'd in a Lovers heart,
And in a Virgins too, when ſhe wants help,
To grant me your aſſiſtance, to find out
This man alive, or dead; and I will pay you
In ſervice, tears, or prayers, a world of wealth:
But other treaſure, I have none: alas!
You men have ſtrong hearts; but we feeble maids
Have tender eyes, which only given be
Yo blind themſelves, crying for what they ſee.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why do'ſt thou charge me thus? have I been found
Slow to perform, what I could but imagine
Thy wiſhes were; have I at any time
Tender'd a buſineſſe of mine own, beyond
A vanity of thine? have I not been
As if I were a ſenſleſſe creature, made
To ſerve thee without pow'r of queſtioning,
If ſo, why fear'ſt thou?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: I am ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Come, then let's go; wher's Leocadia?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: I know not Sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Wher's Leocadia?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: I do not know.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Leocadia,
This Tumult made the ſtreets as dead as night,
A man may talk as freely: what's become
Of Leocadia?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: She's run away.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Begone, and let us never more behold
Each others face, till we may both together
Faſten our eyes on her: accurſed be
Thoſe tender cozening names of charity,
And naturall affection, they have loſt
Me only by obſerving them, what coſt
Travell, and fruitleſſe wiſhes may in vain
Search through the world, but never find again.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Good Sir be patient, I have done no fault
Worthy this baniſhment.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Yes, Leocadia,
The Lady ſo diſtreſs'd, who was content
To lay her ſtory, and to lay her heart
As open as her ſtory to your ſelf,
Who was content, that I ſhould know her Sex,
Before diſſembl'd, and to put her ſelf
Into my conduct, when I undertook
Safely to guard, is in this Tumult loſt.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: And can I help it Sir?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: No, would thou couldſt,
You might have done, but for that ſcale religion
You woman bear to ſwownings, you do pick
Your times to faint, when ſome body is by:
Bound or by nature, or by love, or ſervice
To raiſe you from that well diſſembled death:
Inform me but of one that has been found
Dead in her private chamber by her ſelf,
Where ſickneſſe would no more forbear, then here,
And I will quit the reſt for her.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: I know not
What they may do, and how they may diſſemble;
But by my troth, I did not.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: By my troth,
Would I had try'd; would I had let thee layen,
And followed her.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: I would you had done ſo
Rather, then been ſo angry: wher's Antonio?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why do'ſt thou vex me with theſe queſtions?
Ile tell thee where, he's carried to the Gallyes,
There to be chain'd, and row, and beat, and row
With knotted ropes, and pizzels; if he ſwound,
He has a dotes of bisket.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: I am glad
He is alive.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Was ever man thus troubled,
Tell me where Leocadia is?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Good brother be not ſo haſty, and I think I can:
You found no error in me, when I firſt▪
Told you ſhe was a woman, and beleeve me
Sometning I have found out, which makes me think,
Nay, almoſt know ſo well, that I durſt ſwear
She follow'd hurt Antonio.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What do we
sp.stage: Enter the Governor, two Attendees, and the Townſmen.
sp.l: Then lingring here; we will aboard the Gallyes
And find her.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Made he a ſhot into the Town?

sp.speaker: 1. Attend.
sp.l: He did Sir.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Call back thoſe Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 1. Attend.
sp.l: The Governour, commands you back.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: We will obey him Sir.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: You gave him cauſe ſo ſhoot, I know; he is
So far from raſh offence, and holds with me
Such curious friendſhip: could not one of you
Have call'd me while 'twas doing, ſuch an uproar,
Before my dore too?

sp.speaker: 1. Townſm.
sp.l: By my troth Sir, we were ſo buſy in the publick cauſe, of our own
Private falling out, that we forgot it; at home we ſee now
You were not, but as ſoon as the ſhot made us fly, we ran
Away as faſt as we could to ſeek your honour.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: 'Twas gravely done; but no man tels the cauſe
Or chance, or what it was that made you differ.

sp.speaker: 1. Townſ.
sp.l: For my part Sir, if there were any that I knew
Of, the ſhot drove it out of my head: do you know any neighbours.

sp.speaker: all.
sp.l: Not we, not we.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Not wel nor can you tell.

sp.speaker: 1. Attend.
sp.l: No other cauſe,
But the old quarrell betwixt the Town and the Gallyes.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Come neerer Gentlemen: what are your names?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: My name Philippo.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: And mine Theodoro.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Strangers you are it ſeems.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Newly ariv'd.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Then you are they begun this Tumult.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: No Sir.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Speak one of you.

sp.speaker: 1. Attend.
sp.l: They are not, I can quiet 'em.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Yet we ſaw part, and an unhappy part
Of this debate, a long ſought friend of ours
Strook down for dead, and borne unto the Gallyes,
His name is Markantonio.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: And another
Of our own company, a Gentleman
Of noble birth, beſides accompanied
With all the gifts of nature, raviſh'd hence?
We know not how, in this diſſention.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Get you home all, and work; and when I hear
You meddle with a weapon any more
But thoſe belonging to your Trades, ile lay you
Where your beſt Cuſtomers ſhall hardly find you. Exit Townſmen.
I am ſorry gentlemen, I troubled you,
Being both ſtrangers; by your tgngues, and looks,
Of worth: To make ye ſome part of amends
If there be any thing in this poor Town
Of Barcelona that you would command,
Command me.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Sir, this wounded Gentleman,
If it might pleaſe you, if your pow'r and love
Extend ſo far, I would be glad to wiſh
Might be remov'd into the Town for cure:
The Gallyes ſtay not, and his wound I know
Cannot endure a voyage.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Sir, he ſhall,
I warrant you; Go call me hither Sirrah,
One of my other Servants. Exit 1. attendant.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: And beſides.
The gentleman we loſt, Signior Franciſco,
Shall he be render'd too.

sp.speaker: Gover.
sp.l: And he Sir too: Go ſirrah, bear this ring
To Rodorigo, my moſt noble friend,
The Generall of the Gallys: Tell him this. Exit ſervant:

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Now we ſhall have 'em both.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Bleſt be thy thoughts
For apprehending this: bleſt be thy breath
For utring it.

sp.speaker: Gover.
sp.l: Come gentlemen, you ſhall
Enter my roof: and I will ſend for Surgeons,
And you ſhall ſee your friends here preſently.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: His name was Markantonio.

sp.speaker: Gover.
sp.l: I know it,
And have ſent word ſo.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Did you not forget
Franciſco's name?

sp.speaker: Gover.
sp.l: Nor his: you'ar truly welcome,
To talk about it more, were but to ſay
The ſame word often over: you are welcome. Exeunt.

div.head: SCAENA SECUNDA.
div.stage: Enter Markantonio, carried. Leocadia following, and the Servant. 2 Soldiers carrying him.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: This is the houſe Sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Enter it, I pray you,
For I am faint, although I think my wound
Be nothing. Soldiers, leave us now: I thank you.

sp.speaker: 1. Sold.
sp.l: Heaven ſend you health Sir.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Let me lead you in.

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.l: My wounds not in my feet; I ſhall entreat 'em
I hope to bear me ſo far. Exit.

sp.speaker: 2. Sold.
sp.l: How ſeriously theſe land men fled, when our Generall made a
Shot, as if he had been a warning to cal 'em to their Hall.

sp.speaker: 1. Sold.
sp.l: I cannot blame 'em: What a man have they now in the
Town, able to maintain a Tumult, or uphold a matter out
Of ſquare if need be: O the quiet hurley burleys that I
Have ſeen in this Town, when we have fought four howrs
Together, and not a man amongſt us ſo impertinent or
Modeſt to ask why? but now the pillars that bare
Up this bleſſed Town in that regular debate, and
Scambling, are dead, the more's the pity.

sp.speaker: 2. Sold.
sp.l: Old Ignatio lives ſtill.

sp.speaker: 1. Sold.
sp.l: Yes, I know him: he will do pretily well at a mans liver:
But where is there a man now living in the Town
That hath a ſteady hand, and underſtands Anotomy
Well? if it come to a particular matter of the lungs,
Or the ſpleen, why? alas Ignatio is to ſeek; are
There any ſuch men left as I have known, that
Would ſay they would hit you in this place? is there
Ever a good heartiſt, or a member percer, or a
Small-gut man left in the Town, anſwer
Me that.

sp.speaker: 2. Sold.
sp.l: Maſſe, I think there be not.

sp.speaker: 1. Sold.
sp.l: No, I Warrant thee. Come, come, 'tis time
We were at the Gallys. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Governour, Eugenia, Markantonio, Philippo, Theodoſia, Leocadia, Attendants.

sp.speaker: Gover.
sp.l: Sir, you may know by what I ſaid already,
You may command my houſe; but I muſt beg
Pardon to leave you, if the publique buſineſſe
Forc'd me not from you, I my ſelf ſhould call it
Unmannerly: but good Sir, do you give it
A milder name: it ſhall not be an houre
Ere I return.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Sir, I was nere ſo poor
In my own thoughts, as that I want a means
To require this with.

sp.speaker: Gover.
sp.l: Sir, within this houre. Exit.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: This the Lady that I quarrell'd for:
O luſt, if wounds cannot reſtrain thy power,
Let ſhame: nor do I feel my hurt at all,
Nor is it ought, only I was well beaten:
If I purſue it, all the civill world
That ever did imagine the content
Found in the band of man and wife unbroke,
The reverence due to houſholds, or the blemiſh
That may be ſtuck upon poſterity
Will catch me, bind me, burn upon my forehead,
This is the wounded ſtranger, that receiv'd
For charity into a houſe, attempted:
I will not do it.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Sir, how do you now?
That you walk off.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Worſe Madam, then I was;
But it will over.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Sit, and reſt a while.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Where are the Surgeons?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Sir, it is their manner,
When they have ſeen the wound eſpecially,
The patient being of worth, to go conſult,
Which they are now at in another room,
About the dreſſing.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Madam, I do feel
My ſelf not well.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Alas!

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: How do you Sir.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Will you drink waters?

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: No good Madam, 'tis not
So violent upon me; nor I think
Any thing dangerous: But yet there are
Some things that ſit ſo heavy on my conſcience
That will perplex my mind, and ſtop my cure,
So that unleſſe I utter 'em. A ſcratch
Here on my thumb will kill me: Gentlemen,
I pray you leave the room, and come not in
Your ſelves, or any other till I have
Open'd my ſelf to this moſt honour'd Lady.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: We will not.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: O bleſt! he will diſcover now
His love to me.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Now he will tell the Lady
Our Contract. Exit.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I do beleeve he will confeſſe to me
The wrong he did a Lady in the ſtreets;
But I forgive him.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Madam, I perceive
My ſelf grow worſe and worſe.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Shall I call back your friends?

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: O no; but ere I do impart
What burthens me ſo ſore, let me entreat you,
(For there is no truſt in theſe Surgeons)
To look upon my wound; it is perhaps
My laſt requeſt: But tell me truly too,
That muſt be in: how far you do imagine
Ir will have pow'r upon me.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Sir, I will.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: For heavens ſake, ſoftly: oh, I muſt needs lay
My head down eaſily, whilſt you do it.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Do Sir,
'Tis but an ordinary blow; a child
Of mine has had a greater, and been well;
Are you faint hearted?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Oh.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Why do you ſigh?
There is no danger in the world in this;
I wonder it ſhould make a man ſit down;
What do you mean, why do you kiſſe my breaſts?
Lift up your head, your wound, may well endure it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O Madam, may I not expreſſe affection,
Dying-affection too I fear, to thoſe
That do me favors, ſuch as this of yours.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: If you mean ſo, 'tis well; but what's the buſines
Lies on your conſcience?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I will tell you Madam.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Tel me, and laugh?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: But I wil tel you true
Though I do laugh, I know as well as you
My wound is nothing, nnor the power of earth
Could lay a wound upon me, in your preſence,
That I could feel; But I do laugh to think
How covertly, how far beyond the reach
Of men, and wiſemen too, we ſhal deceive 'em,
Whilſt they imagine I am talking here
With that ſhort breath I have, ready to ſwound
At every full point; you my ghoſtly Mother
To hear my ſad confeſſion, you and I
Will on that bed within, prepar'd for me,
Debate the matter privately.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Forbear,
Thou wert but now as welcome to this houſe
As certain cures to ſick men, and juſt now
This ſodain alteration makes thee look
Like plagues come to infect it; if thou knewſt
How loathſom thou wilt be, thou wouldſt intreat
Theſe walls, or poſtes to help thee to a hurt,
Paſt thy diſſimulation.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Gentle Madam
Cal 'em not in?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I will not yee, this place
I know to be within the reach of tongue,
And ears, thou canſt not force me; therefore hear me
What I will tell thee quickly, thou art born
To end ſome way more diſeſteem'd then this,
Or which is worſe, to dye of this hurt yet,
Come gentleman.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Good Modam.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Madam how is't? is Mark-antonio well?
Methinks your looks are alter'd, and I ſee
A ſtrange diſtemper in you.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I am wrought
By that diſſembling man, that fellow worth
Nothing but kicking.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Gentle Madam ſpeak
To me alone, let not them underſtand
His fault, he wil repent it I dare ſwear.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Ile tell it you in private.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Mark-antonio,
How do you?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Stand further off I pray you
Give me ſome ayre.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Good Brother, wil he ſcape,
The Surgeons ſay there is no danger.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Scape?
No doubt he wil.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Alas wil he not leave
This trying all; Madam, I do beſeech you
Let me but ſpeak to him, you and theſe by,
And I dare almoſt promiſe you to make him
Shew himſelf truly ſorrowful to you, beſides a ſtory I ſhal open to you,
Not put in ſo good words but in it ſelf
So full of chance, that you wil eaſily
Forgive my tediouſneſſe, and be wel pleas'd
With that ſo much afflicts me.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Good Sir do.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: And I deſire no interruption
Of ſpeech may trouble me, till I have ſaid
What I wil quickly do.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: What wil ſhe ſay?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Come gentlemen, I pray you lend your ears,
And keep your voyces.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Signior Mark-antonio
How do you?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Oh the Surgeons.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Let me tel you
Who know as wel as you, you do diſſemble,
It is no time to do ſo; leave the thoughts
Of this vain world, forget your fleſh and blood,
And make your ſpirit an untroubled way
To paſſe to what it ought.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You'r not in earneſt?
Why I can walk Sir, and am wel.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: 'Tis true
That you can walk, and do beleeve you'r wel:
It is the nature, as your Surgeons ſay
Of theſe wounds, for a man to go, and talk,
Nay merrily, till his laſt hour, his minute:
For heaven ſake ſir, ſit down again.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Alas
Where are the Surgeons?

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Sir, they will not come,
If they ſhould dreſſe you, you would dye they ſay
Ere one told twenty; trouble not your mind,
Keep your head warm, and do not ſtir you body,
And you may live an hour.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Oh heavens, an hour?
Alas, it is to little to remember
But half the wrongs that I have done; how ſhort
Then for contrition, and how leaſt of all
For ſatisfaction?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: But you deſire
To ſatisfie.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Heaven knows I do.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Then know
That I am he, or ſhe, or what you will
Moſt wrong'd by you; your Leocadia,
I know you muſt remember me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Oh heaven!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: That loſt her friends, that loſt her fathers houſe,
That loſt her fame, in looſing of her Sex,
With theſe ſtrange garments, there is no excuſe
To hinder me, it is within your power
To give me ſatisfaction; you have time
Left in this little peece of life to do it:
Therefore I charge you for your conſcience ſake,
And for our fame, which I would fain have live
When both of us are dead; to celebrate
That Contract; which you have both ſeal'd and ſworn
Yet ere you dye, which muſt be haſtily
Heaven knows.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Alas, the ſting of conſcience
To death-ward for our faults: draw neerer all
And hear what I unhappy man ſhal ſay;
Firſt Madam I deſire your pardon; next
(I fell my ſpirits fail me) Gentlemen
Let me ſhake hands with you, and let's be friends,
For I have done wrong upon wrong ſo thick
I know not where, that every man methinks
ſhould be mine enemy; Forgive me both.
Laſtly 'tis true (oh I do feel the power
Of death ſeize on me) that I was contracted
By ſeal and oath to Leocadia;
(I muſt ſpeak faſt, becauſe I fear my life
Will elſe be ſhorter then my ſpeech would be)
But 'tis impoſſible to ſatisfie
You Leocadia, but by repentance,
Though I can dyingly, and boldly ſay
I know not your diſhonor, yet that was
Your vertue, and not mine, you know it wel;
But herein lies th' impoſſibility,
O Theodoſia, Theodoſia
I was betroth'd to Theodoſia
Before I ever ſaw thee; heaven forgive me
She is my wife this half hour whilſt I live.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: That's I, that's I, I 'me Theodoſia,
Hear me a litle now, who have not ſuffer'd
Diſgrace at all methinks, ſince you confeſs
What I ſo long have ſought for, here is with me
Philippo too, my Brother.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I am glad;
All happineſs to him; Come let me kiſs thee
Beg pardon of that Maid for my offence,
And let me further, with a dying breath
Tell in thine ear, the reſt of my deſires.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I am afraid they wil all four turn women
If we hold longer talk.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Alas there is
No hope for me; that's Theodoſia
And that her Brother, I am only ſorry
I was beholding to 'em; I will ſearch
Over the world, as careleſſe of my fortunes,
As they of me, till I can meet a curſe
To make theſe almoſt-killing ſorrows worſe. Exit.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Sir, as I live ſhe ly'd, only to draw
A juſt confeſſion from you, which ſhe hath
A happy one for me, ask of this Lady,
Ask of my Brother.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Sir, ſhe did diſſemble,
Your wound is nothing.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Leocadia's gone. Exit.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Riſe up, and ſtir your ſelf, 'tis but amazement
And your imagination that afflicts you,
Look you Sir now.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I think 'tis ſo indeed.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: The Surgeons do not come, becauſe they ſwear
It needs no dreſſing.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: You ſhal talk with 'em
Within, for your own fancy.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Where's your Brother And Leocadia?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Within Belike.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I feel my ſelf methinks as well as ever.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Keep then your mind ſo too; I do forgive
The fault you did to me; But here is one
Muſt not be wrong'd hereafter.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Neither ſhall ſhee
When I make jeſts of oathes again, or make
My luſt play with religion, when I leave
To keep true joyes for her, and yet within
My ſelf true ſorrow for my paſſed deeds
May I want grace, when I would fain repent,
And find a great and ſodain puniſhment. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: WHere is mine Hoſt, did not he ſee him neither?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Not I, y faith Sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nor the muleter?

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Nay he is paſt ſeeing, unleſſe it be in's ſleep,
By this time; all his viſions were the pots,
Three hours ſince Sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Which way ſhould ſhe take?
Nay, look you now; do you all ſtand ſtil? good god
You might have lighted on him, now, this inſtant?
For loves ſake ſeek him out, who ever find him
I will reward his fortune as his diligence;
Get all the Town to help, that will behir'd,
Their pains ile turn to an annall holiday,
If it ſhal chance, but one bring word of her,
Pray you about it.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Her ſir? who do you mean?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: (I had forgot my ſelf) the Page I meant
That came along with us.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: He you give the clothes too?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I ga' the clothes to; Raſcal.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Nay good Sir.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Why do'ſt thou mention, or upbraid my courteſies Slave?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: For your honor Sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Wretch; I was honor'd,
That ſhe would wear 'em (he, I would ſay) 's death?
Go, get, and find him out, or never ſee me,
I ſhal betray my love ere I poſſeſs it,
Some ſtar direct me, or ill planet ſtrike me. Exit Phil.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Beſt to divide.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Ile this way.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: And I this.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.l: I, as you, find him for a real.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: 'Tis done.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: My courſe is now directly to ſome piehouſe
I know the Pages compaſſe.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: I think rather
The ſmock ſide o' the Town, the ſurer harbor
At his years to put in.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: If I do find
The hungry haunt, I take him by the teeth now.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: I by the tail, yet I as you.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: No more. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Dear Leocadia, where canſt thou be fled
Thus like a ſpirit hence? and in a moment?
What cloud can hide thee from my following ſearch
If yet thou art a body? ſure ſhe hath not
Tane any houſe? ſhe did too late leave one
Where all humanity of a place receiv'd her,
And would (if ſhe had ſtayd) have help'd to right
The wrong her fortune did her; yet ſhe muſt
Be inter'd ſomewhere, or be found, no ſtreet,
Lane, paſſage, corner, turn, hath ſcap'd enquiry:
If her diſpair had raviſh'd her to ayre
Shee could not yet be rarefied ſo Enter Incube.
But ſome of us ſhould meet her? though their eyes
Perhaps be leaden, and might turn; mine would
Strike out a lightning for her, and divide
A miſt as thick as ever darkſneſſe was,
Nay ſee her through a quarry; they do lye,
Lye groſly that ſay love is blind: by him,
And heaven they lye; he has a ſight can pierce
Through Ivory as clear as it were horn,
And reach his object.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Sir hee's found, hee's found.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Ha? where? But reach that happy note again
And let it reliſh truth, thou art an Angel.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Hee's here; faſt by ſir, calling for a Boat
To go aboard the Gallies.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Where, where; hold thee. Exit.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: He might ha' kept this now, I had nought to ſhew for 't
If he had had the wit t' have gone from 's word,
Theſe direct men, they are no men of faſhion,
Talk what you will, this is a very ſmelt. Exit.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Upon your art Sir, and your faith to aſſiſt it
Shal I beleeve you then hiS wounds not mortal?

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.l: Sir 'tis not worth your queſtio; leſſe your fear.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: You do reſtore me Sir, I pray you accept
This ſmal remembrance of a fathers thanks
For ſo aſſur'd a benefit.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.l: Excuſe me.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Sir I can ſpare it, and muſt not beleeve
But that your fortune may receive 't, except
You 'ld ha' me think you live not by your practiſe.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.l: I crave your pardon Sir; you teach me manners.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I crave your love and friendſhip, and require
As I have made now, both my ſelf and buſineſſe
A portion of your care, you wil but bring me
Under the perſon of a call'd aſſiſtant
To his next opening, where I may but ſee him,
And utter a few words to him in private,
And you will merit me; For I am loth
Since here I have not to appear my ſelf,
Or to be known unto the Governor,
Or make a tumult of my purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.l: Neither
I hope wil be your need Sir; I ſhal bring you
Both there, and off again without the hazard. Exeunt.

div.head: SCAENA QUARTA.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Wil you not hear me?

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: I have heard ſo much
Wil keep me deaf for ever; No, Mark-antonie
After thy ſentence, I may hear no more,
Thou haſt pronounc'd me dead.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Appeal to reaſon,
She will reprieve you from the power of grief,
Which rules but in her abſence; Hear me ſay
A ſoveraign meſſage from her, which in duty,
And love to your own ſafety, you ought hear:
Why do you ſtrive ſo? whither would you fly?
You cannot wreſt your ſelf away from care
You may from councel; you may ſhift your place
But not your perſon; and another Clyme
Makes you no other.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Oh.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: For paſſions ſake,
(Which I do ſerve, honor, and love in you)
If you will ſigh, ſigh here; If you would vary
A ſigh to tears, or out-cry, do it here.
No ſhade, no deſart, darkneſſe, nor the grave
Shal be more equal to your thoughts then I,
Only but hear me ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: What would you ſay?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: That which ſhall raiſe your heart, or pul down mine,
Quiet your paſſion, or provoke mine own;
We muſt have both one balſame, or one wound,
For know (lov'd fair) ſince the firſt providence
Made me your reſcew, I have read you through,
And with a wondring pity, look'd on you,
I have obſerv'd the method of your blood,
And waited on it even with ſympathy
Of a like red, and paleneſſe in mine own;
I knew which bluſh was angers, which was loves,
Which was the eye of ſorrow, which of truth;
And could diſtinguiſh honor from diſdain
In every change; And you are worth my ſtudy:
I ſaw your voluntary miſery
Suſtain'd in travel: A diſguiſed Maid
Wearied with ſeeking: and with finding loſt,
Neglected, where you hop'd moſt; or put by;
I ſaw it, and have laid it to my heart,
And though it were my Siſter, which was righted,
Yet being by your wrong, I put off nature,
Could not be glad, where I was bound to triumph,
My care for you, ſo drown'd reſpect of her,
Nor did I only apprehend your bonds,
But ſtudyed your releaſe: and for that day
Have I made up a ranſom, brought you health
Preſervative 'gainſt chance, or injury
Pleaſe you apply it to the grief; my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Humh.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nay do not think me leſſe then ſuch a cure,
Antonio was not; And 'tis poſſible
Philippo may ſucceed: My blood and houſe
Are as deep rooted: and as fairly ſpread,
As Mark-antonio's, and in that, all ſeek,
Fortune hath given him no precedency:
As for our thanks to Nature I may burn
Incenſe as much as he: I ever durſt
Walk with Antonio oy the ſelf-ſame light
At any feaſt, or triumph, and nev'r car'd
Which ſide my Lady or her woman took
In their ſurvey; I durſt have told my tale too
Though his diſcourſe new ended.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: My repulſe.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Let not that torture you, which makes me happy
Nor think that conſcience (fair) which is no ſhame
'Twas no repulſe, I was your dowry rather:
For then methought a thouſand graces met
To make you lovely, and ten thouſand ſtories
Of conſtant vertue, which you then out-reach'd,
In one example, did proclaim you rich
Nor do I think you wretched, or diſgrac'd
After this ſuffring, and do therefore take
Advantage of your need; but rather know
You are the charge and buſineſſe of thoſe powers,
Who, like beſt Tutors, do inflict hard tasks
Upon great Natures, and of nobleſt hopes;
Read trivial leſſons, and half lines to ſluggs;
They that live long and never feel miſchance,
Spend more then half their age in ignorance.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: 'Tis wel you think ſo.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: You ſhal think ſo too,
You ſhal ſweet Leocadia, and do ſo.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Good Sir no more; you have too fair a ſhape
To play ſo foul a part in, as the Tempter:
Say that I could make peace with fortune, who,
Who ſhould abſolve me of my vow yet; ha?
My Contract made?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Your Contract?

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Yes, my Contract,
Am I not his? his wife?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Sweet, nothing leſſe.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: I have no name then?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Truly then you have not;
How can you be his wife, who was before
Anothers husband?

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Oh, though he diſpence
With his faith given, I cannot with mine.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: You do miſtake (cleer ſoul) his precontract
Doth annul yours, and you have giv'n no faith
That ties you in religion, or humanity,
You rather ſin againſt that greater precept,
To covet what's anothers; Sweet, you do
Beleeve me, who dare not urge diſhoneſt things,
Remove that ſcruple therefore, and but take
Your dangers now, into your judgements skale
And weigh them with your ſafeties: Think but whither
Now you can go: what you can do to live?
How neer you ha' barr'd all Ports to your own ſuccor,
Except this one that I here open: Love
Should you be left alone, you were a prey
To the wild luſt of any, who would look
Upon this ſhape like a temptation
And think you want the man you perſonate
Would not regard this ſhift, which love put on
As vertue forc'd but covet it like vice;
So ſhould you live the ſlander of each Sex,
And be the child of error, and of ſhame,
And which is worſe, even Mark-antonie
Would be cal'd juſt, to turn a wanderer off,
And Fame report you worthy his contempt;
Where if you make new choyce, and ſetle here
There is no further tumult in this flood.
Each currant keeps his courſe, and all ſuſpitions
Shal return honors: Came you forth a Maid?
Go home a Wife? alone? and in diſguiſe?
Go home a waited Leocadia:
Go home, and by the vertue of that Charm
Transform all miſchiefs, as you are transform'd;
Turn your offended Fathers wrath to wonder,
And all his loud grief to a ſilent welcome:
Unfold the Riddles you have made, what ſay you?
sp.stage: Enter Sanchio carried, Alphonſo, and Servants.
sp.l: Now is the time; delay is but deſpair,
If you be chang'd, let a kiſſe tell me ſo.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: I am: but how, I rather feel then know.

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.l: Come Sir; you are welcome now to Barcellona,
Take off my hood.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Who be theſe? ſtay, let's view 'em?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: 'Twas a long journey: are you not weary Sir?

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.l: Weary? I could have rid it in mine Armour.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Alas!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What ayl you deer?

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: It is my Father.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Your Father: which?

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: He that is carried: oh
Let us make hence.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: For loves ſake: good my heart.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Into ſome houſe before he ſee me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Deer,
Be not thus frighted.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: O his wrath is tempeſt.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Sweet, take your ſpirit to you, and ſtay bee't he,
He cannot know you in this habit, and me
I'me ſure he leſſe knows, for he never ſaw me.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Ha? who is that? my Son Philippo?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Why, what make you here? Is this Salamanca?
And that your ſtudy? ha? nay ſtay him too,
Wee'l ſee him by his leave.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: You muſt not ſtrive Sir.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: No, no, come neer.

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.l: My daughter: Leocadia?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: How Sir: your daughter?

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.l: Yes Sir, and as ſure
As that's your Son: Come hither: what now? run
Out o' your ſex? breech'd? was't not enough
At once to leave thy Father, and thine honor,
Unleſſe th' hadſt quit thy ſelf too.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Sir what fault
She can be urg'd off, I muſt take on me
The guilt, and puniſhment.

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.l: You muſt Sir: how
If you ſhal not, though you muſt? I deal not
With boys Sir; I, you have a Father here
Shal do me right.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Thou art not mad Philippo?
Art thou Mark-antonie? Son to Leonardo?
Our buſineſſe is to them.

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.l: No, no, no, no,
Ile ha' the buſineſſe now: with you, none elſe,
Pray you let's ſpeak, in private: (carry me to him)
Your Son's the raviſher Sir, and here I find him:
I hope you'l give me cauſe to think you noble,
And do me right, with your ſword ſir, as becomes
One gentleman of honor to another;
All this is fair Sir: here's the ſea faſt by,
Upon the ſands, we will determine
'Tis that I call you too; let's make no days on't,
Ile lead your way; to the ſeaſide Raſcals.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Sir
I would beſeech your ſtay; he may not follow you.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: No, turn ile kill him here then: Slaves, Rogues, Blocks
Why do you not bear me to him? ha' you been
Acquainted with my motions, loggs, ſo long
And yet not know to time 'em.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Were you Sir
Not impotent.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Hold you your peace Boy.

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.l: Impotent
'Death ile cut his throat firſt, and then his Fathers.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: You muſt provide you then a ſharper razor
Then is your tongue, for I not fear your ſword.

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.l: 'Heart bear mee to either of 'em.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Pray Sir your patience.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: My curſe light on thee if thou ſtay him.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Hold.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Why, what's the matter, Gentlemen, what tumult
Is this you raiſe i'th ſtreet? before my door?
Know you what 'tis to draw a weapon here.

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.l: Yes, and to uſe it (bear me up to him, Rogues)
Thus, at a Traytors heart.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Truer then thine.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Strike, ſtrike; Some of the people diſarm 'em,
Kil 'em if they reſiſt.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nay generous ſir
Let not your courteſie turn fury now.

sp.speaker: Gover.
sp.l: Lay hold upon 'em, take away their weapons,
I wil be worth an anſwer, ere we part.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Tis the Governour ſir.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I yield my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: My Sword? what thinkſt thou of me? pray thee tell me.

sp.speaker: 1 Attend.
sp.l: As of a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: No more.

sp.speaker: 1 Attend.
sp.l: Of worth,
And quality.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: And I ſhould quit my Sword
There were ſmall worth or quality in that friend;
Pray thee learn thou more worth and quality
Then to demand it.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Force it I ſay.

sp.speaker: 1 Atten.
sp.l: The Governour
You heare, commands.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: The Governour ſhall pardon me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How, Leocadia gone again? Exit Phil.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: He ſhall friend
I'th point of honour; by his leave, ſo tell him,
His perſon and authority I acknowledge,
And do ſubmit me to it; but my Sword,
He ſhal excuſe me, were he fifteen Governours;
That and I dwell together, and muſt yet
Till my hands part, aſſure him.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I ſay force it.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Stay, heare me. Haſt thou ever read Curanza?
Underſtandſt thou honour, Noble Governour?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: For that we'l have more fit diſpute.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Your name ſir.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: You ſhall know that too: But on colder termes,
Your blood and brain are now too hot to take it.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Force my Sword from me? this is an affront.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Bring 'em away.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: You'l do me reparation. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I have for ever loſt her, and am loſt,
And worthily: my tameneſſe hath undone me;
She's gone hence, aſham'd of me: yet I ſeek her.
Will ſhe be ever found to me again,
Whom ſhe ſaw ſtand ſo poorly, and dare nothing
In her defence, here, when I ſhould have drawn
This Sword out like a meteor, and have ſhot it
In both our parents eyes, and left 'em blind
Unto their impotent angers? O I am worthy
On whom this loſſe and ſcorn ſhould light to death
Without the pity that ſhould wiſh me better,
Either alive, or in my Epitaph.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Well ſon, your father is too neere himſelfe
And hath too much of nature to put off
Any affection that belongs to you.
I could have onely wiſh'd you had acquainted
Her father, whom it equally concerns,
Though y'had preſum'd on me: it might have open'd
An eaſier gate, and path to both our joyes:
For though I am none of thoſe flinty Fathers
That when their children do but naturall things,
Turn rock and offence ſtreight: yet Marc-antonio,
All are not of my quarry.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Tis my feare ſir;
And if hereafter I ſhould ere abuſe
So great a piety, it were my malice.

sp.speaker: Atten.
sp.l: We muſt intreat you Gentlemen to take
Another room, the Governour is comming
Here, on ſome buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: We will give him way.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: I will have right ſir on you; that believe,
If there be any Marſhals Court in Spaine.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: For that ſir we ſhall talke.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: — doe not ſlight me,
Though I am without a Sword.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Keep to your chaire ſir.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: —Let me fall, and hurle my chaire! (ſlaves) at him.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: You are the more temperd man ſir: let me intreat
Of you the manner how this brawle fell out.

sp.speaker: Alph
sp.l: Fell out? I know not how: nor do I care much:
But here we came ſir to this Town together,
Both in one buſineſſe and one wrong, engag'd
To ſeeke one Leonardo an old Genoeſe,
I ha' ſaid enough there; would you more? falſe father
Of a falſe ſonne, cal'd Marc-antonio,
Who had ſtole both our daughters; and which father
Conſpiring with his ſonne in treachery,
It ſeemd, to fly our ſatisfaction,
Was, as we heard, come private to this Town
Here to take ſhip for Italy.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: You heard
More then was true then: by the feare, or falſhood,
And though I thought not to reveale my ſelfe
(Pardon my manners in't to you) for ſome
Important reaſons; yet being thus character'd
And challeng'd, know I dare appeare, and doe
To who dares threaten.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I ſay he is not worthy
The name of man, or any honeſt preface,
That dares report or credit ſuch a ſlander.
Doe you ſir ſay it?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Sir, I doe ſay it.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Hold,
Is this your father Signior Marc-antonio?
You have ill requited me thus to conceale him
From him would honour him, and do him ſervice.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Twas not his fault ſir.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Where's my Lord.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Sweet heart.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Know you theſe Gentlemen? they are all the fathers
Unto our friends.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: So it appeares my Dove.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Sir I ſay nothing: I doe want a Sword,
And till I have a Sword I will ſay nothing.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Good ſir command theſe Gentlemen their Armes;
Entreat 'em as your friends, not as your priſoners.
Where be their Swords?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Reſtore each man his weapon.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: It ſeems thou haſt not read Curanza, fellow
I muſt have reparation of honour,
As well as this; I finde that wounded.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Sir,
I did not know your quality, if I had
Tis like I ſhould have done you more reſpects.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: It is ſufficient, by Caranza's rule.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I know it is ſir.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Have you read Caranza Lady?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: If you mean him that writ upon the duell,
He was my kinſman.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Lady, then you know
By the right noble writings of your kinſman,
My honour is as deere to me, as the Kings.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Tis very true ſir.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Therefore I muſt crave
Leave to goe on now with my firſt dependance.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: What ha you more?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: None here good Signior.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: I will, refer me to Claranza ſtill.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Nay love, I prethee let me mannage this.
With whom is't ſir?

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: With that falſe man Alphonſo.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Why he has th'advantage ſir in legs.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: But I
In truth, and hand and heart, and a good Sword.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: But how if he will not ſtand you Sir.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: For that,
Make it no queſtion Lady, I will ſticke
My feet in earth down by him, where he dare.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: O would thou wouldſt.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Ile do't.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Let me kiſſe him.
I feare thou wilt not yet.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Why Gentlemen,
If you'l proceed according to Curanza,
Me thinks an eaſier way, were too good chaires,
So you would be content ſir to be bound,
'Cauſe he is lame, ile fit you with like weapons,
Piſtols and Ponyards, and ev'n end it. If
The difference between you be ſo mortall.
It cannot be tane up.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Tane up? take off
This head firſt.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Come bind me in a chaire.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Yes, do.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: What mean you, Dove.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Let me alone,
And ſet 'em at their diſtance: when you ha' done
Lend me two Ponyards; ile have Piſtols ready
Quickly. Exit.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: She is not here Marc-antonio.
Saw you not Leocadia?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Not I brother.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Brother let's ſpeak with you; you were falſe unto her.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I was, but have ask'd pardon: why do you urge it?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: You were not worthy of her.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: May be I was not;
But tis not well, you tell me ſo.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: My ſiſter
Is not ſo faire.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It skils not.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nor ſo vertuous.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes, ſhe muſt be as vertuous.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I would faine—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What brother?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Srike you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I ſhall not beare ſtrokes
Though I do theſe ſtrange words.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Will you not kill me?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: For what good brother?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why, for ſpeaking well
Of Leocadia.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No indeed.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nor ill
Of Theodoſia?

div.stage: Enter Eugenia, Leocadia, Theodoſia, and one with two Piſtols.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Neither.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Fare you well then.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Nay you ſhall have as Noble ſeconds too
As ever duelliſts had; give 'em their weapons:
Now S^t Iago.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Are they charg'd?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Charg'd ſir,
I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Would they were well diſcharg'd.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: I like a Sword much better I confeſſe.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Nay wherefore ſtay you? ſhal I mend your mark?
Strike one another, thorough theſe?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: My love.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: My Theodoſia.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: I ha' not the heart.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Why here is a dependance ended.
Unbind that Gentleman; come take here to you
Your ſonnes and daughters, and be friends. A feaſt
Waites you within, is better then your fray:
Lovers, take you your own, and all forbeare
Under my roofe, either to bluſh or feare
My love, what ſay you; could Cuzanza himſelfe
Carry a buſineſſe better?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: It is well:
All are content I hope, and we well eaſ'd,
If they for whom we have done all this be pleaſ'd.

div.head: PROLOGVE.
div.l: TO this place Gentlemen, full many a day
We have bid ye welcome; and to many a Play:
And thoſe whoſe angry ſoules were not diſeaſd
With law, or lending money, we have pleaſd;
And make no doubt to do again. This night
No mighty matter, nor no light,
We muſt intreat you looke for: A good tale
Told in two houres, we will not faile
If we be perfect to rehearſe ye: New
I am ſure it is, and hanſome; but how true
Let them diſpute that writ it, Ten to one
We pleaſe the women; and I would know that man
Follows not their example. If ye mean
To know the Play well, travell with the Scene.
For it lies upon the road; if we chance tire,
As ye are good men leave us not i'th mire,
Another bayt may mend us: If you grow
A litte gald or weary; cry but hoa,
And we'l ſtay for ye. When our journey ends
Every mans Pot I hope, and all part friends.
